xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAPAMRBUR</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">] WASHINGTON._ American Army intelligence officials recruited leading Nazis as spies following World War II, according to a damning US Justice Department report.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Gestapo officers, SS stormtroopers, propagandists and collaborators were hired by the US military to spy on the Soviets during the Cold War.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The report, released yesterday, listed two Gestapo officials, including one who acted as a double-agent, two SS officers and a pair of priests accused of torturing civilians.</p><p>] LONDON._ Four UK Parliamentarians are to fly to Iran today for a four-day fact-finding tour led by the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr Robert Runcie.</p><p>The Archbishop's special envoy, Terry Waite, has been missing since January 1987.</p><p>] NEW DELHI._ Former Indian defence minister Vishwanath Pratap Singh, now a leading opponent of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, looked set for a big win in a crucial by-election yesterday.</p><p>With half the votes counted, he was leading by more than two to one over Gandhi's chosen candidate Sunil Shastri, son of former prime minister Lal Bahadur Shastri.</p><p>] MANILA._ Two men shot dead a Left-wing leader in front of his home yesterday following a wave of killings of government officials and anti-communist figures in this city by communist guerrillas.</p><p>Ramos Cura, a 44-year-old lawyer, died after being shot twice in the head and once in the body, police said.</p><p>] BEIJING._ A Chinese court yesterday sentenced seven officials, including two local Communist Party leaders, to prison terms of up to five years for neglect of duty in a disastrous forest fire last year that claimed 193 lives.</p><p>] LONDON._ The Princess of Wales has become the first member of the British royal family to be appointed an Honorary Fellow in Dental Surgery at the Royal College of Surgeons.</p><p>She wore a mortar board and black college gown at a ceremony where 120 student dentists were presented with their exam certificates.</p><p>She said she had come by the title via the ""easy route", unlike the dental students. But the Dean of Fellows, Prof Gordon Seward said her ""charming smile", friendly manner and deep interest in children gave her the ideal image for a dental practitioner.</p><p>] KINGSTON._ Reggae poet and street vendor Dennis Lobban, 33, was found guilty yesterday and sentenced to hang for the murder of reggae singing star Peter Tosh.</p><p>On September 11, 1987 when Tosh, radio disc jockey Jeff Dixon and Wilton ""Doc" Brown were murdered by three gunmen who burst into Tosh's home.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF PRINCESS DIANA AFTER BEING HONOURED AS HONORARY FELLOW IN DENTAL SURGERY</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49P8-S030-01S8-G2R0-00000-00<published>1995-04-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">Man on kill charge</p><p nitf:lede="true">A SUNSHINE Coast man will appear in Maroochydore Magistrate's Court</p><p nitf:lede="true">tomorrow facing a charge of murdering his 21-month-old son in September</p><p nitf:lede="true">1993. Victor Korin, 22, was questioned by Sunshine Coast Juvenile Aid</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bureau chief detective Sen Sgt Chris Lill near Bega in New South Wales</p><p nitf:lede="true">on Thursday and extradited on Friday. The toddler, Paul Robert Homer,</p><p nitf:lede="true">died in a Brisbane hospital's intensive care unit.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Crash injures two</p><p>THE driver and a passenger of a car were treated in Royal Brisbane</p><p>Hospital yesterday for injuries received when their vehicle ran out of</p><p>control and crashed into a house on Kedron Brook Road, Wilston, about</p><p>12.45am. The injuries and damage to the property were not thought to be</p><p>serious.</p><p>Cyclone alert</p><p>THE remote West Australian town of Derby has been warned to brace</p><p>itself for winds of 110km/h or higher after tropical cyclone Chloe</p><p>crossed the coast in the far north-east of Western Australia yesterday.</p><p>The Weather Bureau said Chloe was moving inland in a general southerly</p><p>direction and, and on its present course, would pass about 80km</p><p>north-east of Derby. Wind gusts could reach 190km/h at the cyclone's</p><p>centre, but the area the cyclone is passing through is reported to be</p><p>uninhabited.</p><p>Population rise</p><p>THE Tweed Shire covering the New South Wales/Queensland border has</p><p>increased its population by about 2000 _ making it one of the</p><p>fastest-growing regions in NSW. The population grew from 55,440 to</p><p>57,190 from June 1992 to June 1993, according to recent figures from</p><p>the Statistics Bureau.</p><p>Curfew debate</p><p>A BRISBANE University lecturer has entered the vexed Sunshine Coast</p><p>nightclub curfew debate claiming earlier closure would not solve booze</p><p>related problems such as street crime and vandalism. Mooloolaba and</p><p>Noosa, two of the coast's biggest nightclub players, close their doors</p><p>at 3am and the squeeze is on from locals for a midnight</p><p>shutdown.</p><p>Blitz on thefts</p><p>SUNSHINE Coast police have launched a blitz on thefts from cars after</p><p>statistics showed 261 were broken into on the coast last month,</p><p>including well organised hit-and-run raids by motorbike riders lying in</p><p>wait for tourists at National Parks and in beach car parks. Police</p><p>appealed to visitors not to leave valuables in their vehicles.</p><p>29 children die</p><p>A FOREST fire whipped by fierce winds has killed 29 primary-school</p><p>children on an excursion in northern China, local officials said</p><p>yesterday. The children died on April 6 when the fire erupted on a</p><p>mountain in Huairen county in northern Shanxi province, an official</p><p>said.</p><p>Test lab to open</p><p>A HEAVY structures testing laboratory capable of testing full-size</p><p>bridge girders, will be opened at Griffith University's Gold Coast</p><p>campus. The opening comes after increased demand for university staff</p><p>who have previously tested heavy construction objects for the Gold</p><p>Coast City Council.</p><p>Fashion awards</p><p>UP and coming creative talent will be celebrated this week when the</p><p>1995 Gold Coast Fashion Designer Awards are handed out. The awards,</p><p>held at Conrad Jupiters Casino, are organised by the Gold Coast Welfare</p><p>Committee, with all proceeds going to charity.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49KY-9JK0-01S8-G0S3-00000-00<published>1989-01-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>GRAY S</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Kenny rocks boat OLYMPIC canoeist Grant Kenny attacked plans by the Australian Institute of Sport to transfer its kayaking headquarters from the Sunshine Coast to Bond University on the Gold Coast. Kenny told a parliamentary standing committee inquiring into sports funding that the Sunshine Coast had better training facilities. Bouncing Bears BEARS Mark Williams and Phillip Walsh have delighted club officals with their recovery from off-season surgery on injured ankles. Walsh had his left ankle reconstructed while Williams had a bone growth on his foot removed. Two other Bears who required off-season operations, John Fidge (ankle) and Roger Merritt (knee), show no major ill-effects as they start their build-up to the new VFL season. Tee for trouble MELBOURNE._ A blunder by officials means 90 hopefuls will have to tee off again today in an attempt to grab a spot in this week's Coca-Cola Classic. Organisers abandoned a qualifying round at Keysborough Golf Club after allowing players to use the wrong tees. Only 20 qualifiers will join the field of 120. All-rounder is out LONDON._ South African all-rounder Mike Procter's planned move to English cricket club Rishton has collapsed after he demanded an extra $4000 plus $1800 for his wife's airfare from Durban on top of the terms agreed to during negotiations. Forest fire again LONDON._ Goals one minute apart by Gary Parker and Nigel Lough gave Nottingham Forest a 2-1 victory over Tottenham Hotspur and their fifth consecutive English first division soccer victory.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The win spoiled the English debut of Spurs goalie Eric Thorsvedt who made a series of spectacular saves before allowing the goals late in the first half. Soldier at double MARRAKESH._ Belgian soldier Jean Weyts, 28, won the third Marrakesh international marathon from 3000 runners, clocking 2hr15min33sec. Janice Klecker of the US won the women's event in 2:39.19. Speedy trifecta WEST BERLIN._ Gunda Kleeman won the gold medal and compatriots Constanze Moser and Jacqueline Borner the silver and bronze medals to give East Ger- many the women's European speedskating title for the seventh successive year. But the championships attracted only 600 spectators and were saved from financial loss by $35,000 sponsorship. Fall aids winner NORTH Queensland's former world water-ski racing champion Mark Pickering was able to capitalise on a fall to clinch the Queensland open title on the Brisbane River on Sunday. Brisbane's Ian Dipple led the 75km race for 10 laps before a fall allowed Pickering to take the lead. Sunshine Coast junior Sandy Cleaver took out the 60km open women's event. Indoor champions AMSTERDAM._ Brazil has won the inaugural world championship of indoor soccer, beating The Netherlands 2-1 in the final. Belgium lost to Brazil in a penalty shoot- out in the semi-finals and held on until the last minute in extra time before losing the play-off for third place 3-2 against the United States.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4S7J-VJK0-TX4S-M00V-00000-00<published>2008-04-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 12</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>The Canberra Times</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Doctors' behaviour Federal Health Minister Nicola Roxon, in condemning dodgy practices of doctors, said she will come down hard on doctors rorting Medicare ("Watchdog bites doctors over Medicare rort", April 4, p6).</p><p nitf:lede="true">The president of the Australian Medical Association, Rosanna Capolingua, has defended her fellow professionals, saying only a small number are involved in wrongdoing.</p><p nitf:lede="true">There appear to be precedents.</p><p>It is not so long ago that the former government's health minister, Michael Wooldridge, presided over Medicare rorts involving MRI scan scams.</p><p>Not to be left out, Canberra had its very own canine scan scam.</p><p>We need a royal commission to restore our faith in medicos as it is now being significantly eroded.</p><p>Ordinary workers who are perceived to have inherent tendencies to behave improperly are soon dealt with.</p><p>Why should doctors be sacrosanct?</p><p>Albert White, Queanbeyan, NSW Negative gearing Sal Emmanuel says (Letters, April 7) that rents soared following the 1985 (partial) removal of negative gearing for housing investors.</p><p>However, this seems to be a myth.</p><p>The Real Estate Institute of Australia, in its 2003 submission to the Productivity Commission inquiry into first-home ownership, attacked the removal but, significantly, made no claim about soaring rents, and neither should they, because rental yield figures for that period for all of Australia don't back this up.</p><p>Further, Bernie Fraser, head of Treasury throughout the entire period of removal and reinstatement, has also dismissed this as a myth.</p><p>Paul Pollard, O'Connor Lethal street drug Congratulation to Danielle Cronin, Health Reporter, on a thoughtful piece in the paper ("Alarm raised on 'Death' drug", April 7, p1).</p><p>PMA (para-methoxyamphetamine), also know as "Red Mitsubishi" and "Dr Death", has been around for months in ACT nightclubs and on the street.</p><p>It seems to be more popular than ecstasy these days as a lot of youngsters are popping it.</p><p>However, the effects of it put others in places they didn't hope to be, like hospitals and six feet under.</p><p>This drug is killing youth and drug users should be aware that it is highly toxic and has a slow onset of action which leads to overdose.</p><p>It's becoming extremely difficult to detect "Dr Death" because of its colour and form changing.</p><p>That should ring bells in drug users' minds to stop drug use.</p><p>Vanessa Ntloko, Isabella Plains Respecting disabled I was saddened to read the reported comments by Ian Meldrum with respect to a young man with Down syndrome who he had employed in his restaurant ("Holy Grail settles with underpaid workers", April 2, p3).</p><p>If his comments were reported accurately, one can only assume that Meldrum is yet to appreciate that even people with a disability have the right to be spoken of with respect.</p><p>I can imagine that the young man and others like him face many hurdles in entering the workforce and would be very proud when successful in obtaining a job.</p><p>To be referred to in a derogatory manner is very demeaning and reveals much more about the person commenting than the person with the disability.</p><p>Susanne Eaton, Reid Prescribed burning David Horton's claim that prescribed burning causes extensive environmental damage (Letters, April 7) is not supported by scientific evidence.</p><p>Not one scientist in either the 1981 Australian Academy of Science book Fire and the Australian Biota or the 2003 CSIRO book Australia Burning makes such a claim.</p><p>The facts are that Australia's flora and fauna evolved under the influence of fire and that early attempts by European settlers to exclude fire from forested areas failed dismally.</p><p>What scientists agree on is the importance of the concept of fire regimes, taking into account the interplay between intensity, frequency and season of fires in a given area.</p><p>Forest fire experts are advocating the greater use of strategic prescribed burning to create a mosaic of fire regimes across the landscape, along with the need for ongoing research and monitoring of impacts of prescribed burns and wildfires to ensure that fire management continues to be based on sound science.</p><p>Tony Bartlett, Deakin Constitution Ave In "Funding cuts put city plans on hold" (April 7, p1) the National Capital Authority says its hands are tied on development along Constitution Avenue because the Commonwealth (rightly) scrapped costly plans to upgrade it for the time being.</p><p>Also bleating are property owners on the northern frontage of the avenue, who expect to have the massive amounts of traffic that their grand redevelopment schemes will generate taken care of for free.</p><p>The Commonwealth must also scrap its plans to inappropriately site the new ASIO headquarters on Constitution Avenue.</p><p>Not enough work has been done by the NCA to assess the impact its related Griffin Legacy plan for the avenue will have on the residents of Campbell and Reid.</p><p>In fact, the authority doesn't have the resources to do that properly, and never will.</p><p>In reality, the prominence of Constitution Avenue as the base of the national triangle has been forever compromised by Parkes Way.</p><p>So, the well-equipped, reasonably community conscious ACT Planning and Land Authority should deal with all land fronting the north side of the avenue, while a cleaned-out, slimmed- down, design-focused, less-developer- driven NCA concentrates on the south side, without filling the interstitial parkland with wall-to-wall buildings.</p><p>Jack Kershaw, Kambah</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3S9S-91H0-0048-T1PR-00000-00<published>1998-03-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> By Jason Tedjasukmana</p><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, March 26 AFP - Fires continued their advance across Indonesia's charred East Kalimantan province today, razing ancient forests and threatening rare wildlife including the orangutans which are the area's popular symbol.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Borneo island province, where severe drought conditions were hampering fire-fighting efforts and threatening the region's rich biodiversity.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Nunuk Kasyanto, director of the Lories non-governmental organisation dedicated to the preservation of flora and fauna in East Kalimantan, said the wildlife damage was not limited to Indonesian species alone.</p><p>"Birds migrating from Siberia stop here on their way to Australia and are now losing their way because of the smoke," Kasyanto told Agence France-Presse.</p><p> Dozens of horses near the Wanariset research station in Semboja, north of the oil city of Balikpapan, had died from starvation after drought conditions killed off the vegetation in their habitat.</p><p> He said the fires were a problem but added the absence of rain since December was perhaps even more life-threatening.</p><p> "The canopies high up in the trees containing fruit and sources of food for orangutans are dying because of the drought and they can't go down below because there are so many ground fires," Kasyanto said.</p><p> He added one orangutan last week left its habitat near the fire-ravaged Kutai national park to look for food but stumbled upon a group of people stamping out flames.</p><p> "The orangutan apparently got scared and attacked the people, who then reportedly killed the orangutan," he said.</p><p> An expert on orangutan conservation doubted the report but did not rule out the possibility that frightened animals forced out of their habitats would protect themselves if they sensed danger.</p><p> "People have a preconceived notion that orangutans are vicious animals when in actuality they are really peaceful creatures," Barita Manulung, a primate specialist with the World Wide Fund for Nature, told AFP.</p><p> He said no reports gave a detailed account of the orangutan and whether it was a male or female, adult or young.</p><p> "A full grown male orangutan can weigh as much as 107 kilograms and would appear larger than most Indonesian men. Of course, they could look intimidating," he added.</p><p> The loss of vital food sources was leaving the primates weak and vulnerable to to poachers, who mostly export orangutans for sale overseas as pets.</p><p> The estimated population of 2,500 orangutans in the jungles of East Kalimantan was also being cut down by illegal hunting.</p><p> Orangutans are only found in Kalimantan and Malaysia's section of Borneo, and on the Indonesian island of Sumatra.</p><p>East Kalimantan has seen next to no rain since last December as the El Nino weather pattern causes severe drought conditions across the entire Indonesian archipelago.</p><p> The fires have been blamed on large timber and plantation companies and farmers using slash and burn techniques to clear land for planting.</p><p> The government today said it was planning to take three plantation estates in East Kalimantan to court for using fire to clear their land.</p><p> The deputy chairman of the national team to combat forest fire, Major General Adang Ruchiatna, said there was evidence fires had been deliberately set at the plantations, the Suara Pembaruan evening daily reported.</p><p> He said the companies, which he did not identify, used fire to clear their land for new palm oil crops.</p><p> The fires are spreading rapidly through the drought-hit province and have razed more than 130,000 hectares of forest this year.</p><p> Some 300 troops and civilians are struggling to contain fires in the Kutai national park north of the provincial capital Samarinda, where flames are rapidly engulfing the ancient forest.</p><p> AFP hu</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49N0-YKW0-01S8-C49R-00000-00<published>1992-08-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>LESTER MICHAEL <> MOORE MICHAEL <> DIWELL STU</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Funding increase to offset the trim FUNDING for the Forestry Commission will increase this year despite a real-term drop in its timber royalties and a 25 per cent drop in the efficiency of timber workers.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Minister for Forests, Mr Tony Rundle, also announced he expects to name the successful bidder for the southern forests resource by October.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The remaining contenders for the resource are Australian Paper Manufacturers, Forest Resources, and a consortium involving Marubeni Australian and Tasmanian-based Silvicultural Residues.</p><p>The Government also made it clear it was still after an international-scale pulp mill project for the north of the state and would be doing all it could to get such a project back on track.</p><p>The industry also is likely to benefit from the announcement that the Government will allow trialling of B-Double transport trucks on Tasmanian roads later in the year and will fall in line with national trucking regulations by allowing an additional load of 1.5 tonnes on large trucks.</p><p>The Budget also confirmed the Government's commitment to scrapping the rail protection levy, decried by the industry as a financial burden, by July 1995.</p><p>Forestry Commission spending is budgeted to be almost $51.1 million this financial year compared with $49.1 million last year.</p><p>Low pulp, woodchip and timber prices are expected to hold the Commission's timber royalties to $32.9 million in the coming year, an increase of only $200,000 over the previous year and a drop of almost two per cent once inflation is taken into account.</p><p>The Budget also revealed that forest production efficiency had declined dramatically between 1986-86 and 1991-92.</p><p>In 1986-87 each forestry employee was producing 4262 cubic metres of wood. This dropped by 25 per cent to an estimated 3200 cubic metres per employee in 1991-92.</p><p>In an attempt to improve forestry performance the Government announced it will commercialise the operations of the Forestry Commission.</p><p>A first step in this direction was the announcement yesterday that the Commission will increase the dividend it pays the Government from the royalties it receives from industry.</p><p>At present it pays a dividend of 17 per cent on royalties, worth $6.2 million last financial year.</p><p>This year the dividend percentage will increase to 18 per cent although the project benefit for the Government will only be $5.9 million because of the weak state of wood prices on the national and international market.</p><p>A Treasury spokesman said the ultimate aim was to increase the dividend percentage to 19 per cent by 1993-94.</p><p>Mr Rundle also announced that a review would be conducted of the Commission to seek more ways to make it efficient and less of a burden on the Budget.</p><p>Other initiatives announced yesterday included an expanded program of the joint development of eucalypt and pine plantations.</p><p>A small sawmillers' advisory unit will be established to help sawmillers with production demands and ways to improve the marketing of their products.</p><p>The Government also will spend $80,000 on forest fire-fighting training programs.</p><p>Mr Rundle said the Government was committed to initiatives that would make the Commission more efficient and get it working with industry to promote sustainable development and growth.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49N6-SNN0-01S8-G1TT-00000-00<published>1992-02-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>RYAN C</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PAGE 8 CORRECTIONS Return serve WE were appalled at the headline ""Econuts threaten Australia's future" (C-M, January 25), firstly, that you bothered to publish a front page story about it, and secondly, that Sir Bruce Watson said it in the first place. For Sir Bruce, on his way out as managing director of Mt Isa Mines, to label as an ""econut" anyone who understands that economy depends on ecology is a insult to the thousands of Australians who are concerned about the future of the environment and the impact of our lifestyle. Of course, it's nothing new. People used to be ridiculed or persecuted because they believed the earth was round, or that CFCs destroyed ozone, or that Antarctica shouldn't be mined, or that rainforests shouldn't be logged. However, the greens have a name for people who can't recognise an ecological crisis when they see one _ we call them ""pointyheads". But of course, having no desire to engage in petty name-calling and being polite and courteous folk, we keep it to ourselves. _ M. Horstman (Australian Conservation Foundation) and R. Crisp (Queensland Conservation Council). January 29 Think of others I APPEAL to the compassionate and understanding people in the south-east corner to vote ""no" in the daylight saving referendum. A ""real scorcher" in their area is considered a welcome relief from extreme temperatures elsewhere in the state. Mr Goss' decision to introduce daylight saving should have been made on a school oval in Mt Isa, not in air-conditioned comfort.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>And Ald Soorley should have held his pro-daylight saving summit on the same oval to give some balance to their recommendations. Could south-east Queenslanders please do without it so the rest of Queensland does not have to suffer? _ Sally Lauder, Townsville. February 4 IN Britain and New Zealand most potting mixes are derived from the John Innes Institute formula, which uses granulated sphagnum peat moss as its basic humus content. Presumably, it is bacteria-free when gathered. I am not impressed with Queensland potting mixes. The organic content appears to have little or no real moisture-absorbing qualities, is of a fibrous nature and, being black and sooty, is a dirty material with which to work. Surely there are bogs in Australia where sphagnum moss abounds. Legionella pneumophila is far less likely to inhabit this kind of organic material than the gleanings of a burnt-out forest fire. Maybe this is where the health authorities should be searching for an answer to this serious and puzzling problem _ not in the bags of potting mix sold in supermarkets._ Harold T. Hall, Oxenford. February 2 Garden Concerns. No doubt the risk of contracting legionella through potting mix is very small. However in 1960 British newspapers reported the deaths of four men in Holland and five in the south of France from lung infection. The victims were all aged between 40 and 60 and had been using large amounts of potting mix. Later that year five American men died of what was described as a bad chest infection. After this the potting mix issue disappeared but not before there were calls to have the product sterilised before being sold. Frank Carney. Camira. February 2</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49M5-HR10-01S8-C336-00000-00<published>1990-03-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>SIMPSON SAM</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Five minutes of hell, as fire f ighters battled for their lives By SAM SIMPSON IT only lasted about five minutes, but it was the most horrifying time in Terry Crawford's firefighting life.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mr Crawford, 34, captain of the Kingborough brigade, was battling a huge forest fire at the back of Judbury, about 2.30pm yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It was in thick forest and the team of six was in a tanker when a breeze sprung up, swept burning ferns around the tanker and started spot fires.</p><p>"Before then, we knew the fire was behind us and we had time to get out," Mr Crawford said last night.</p><p>"But then it spotted at the side of the road and in front of us and we were engulfed and surrounded.</p><p>"It was all right until we realised we weren't going anywhere.</p><p>"The heat was so intense the fuel vaporised in the tanker, so we couldn't move." The same thing happened to the water pump in the back as the crew tried to keep cool by spraying water on themselves.</p><p>There was a roaring fire all around them, Mr Crawford said.</p><p>Salvation came from a forestry utility behind them.</p><p>Mr Crawford called the driver by radio and within minutes it had pulled alongside.</p><p>"We knew if he didn't make it we wouldn't be getting out, we had had it," Mr Crawford said.</p><p>"You sit there and think what you have done with your life and everything else." Even when the rescue utility drew alongside, Mr Crawford had problems.</p><p>He could not get out of the tanker from his side and had to fling himself out the passenger side and dive into the utility.</p><p>"When I got out that tanker door, all I got was heat and burning embers," he said.</p><p>His crew tumbled into the back of the ute, and that was where they got burnt.</p><p>The blaze had heated the metal to the point where to touch it was to burn and they had to lie in it as they burst through the ring of fire to safety.</p><p>It only took 90 seconds, but every one of those is etched in each firefighter's memory.</p><p>"We weren't far away [from safety] but it might as well have been a kilometre for all the hope we had if that utility hadn't been there," Mr Crawford said.</p><p>Last night, four of the crew members were being treated for burns and smoke inhalation at the Royal Hobart Hospital.</p><p>Almost all the burns to their hands, legs and forearms, were caused by the burning hot metal of the utility.</p><p>A spokesman for the Forestry Commission, Mr Evan Rolley, said the fire near Lonnavale, which was first spotted by helicopter early in the morning, had been spread by very strong, hot northerly winds which had intensified ahead of an expected cooler south-westerly change.</p><p>A weather bureau spokesman said the gusty north to north-westerly winds of the past few days should swing around to the west today, bringing temperatures down to the low 20s in most areas.</p><p>Properties in the region were being protected by firefighters, while the battle to control the blaze in the forest continued.</p><p>Mr Rolley said the fire's cause was of a suspicious nature, and the matter would be investigated.</p><p>The commission's southern regional forester, Mr Graham Sargison, said yesterday that the commission fire crews were busy taking action on 10 fires in the southern forests.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:44DT-WKG0-015G-Y23V-00000-00<published>2001-06-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 89</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>John Hay</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">GOLD Coast couple were distressed when their daughter, working in New York, rang the day after her birthday to say she'd lost her wallet full of credit cards and money. She'd cancelled the cards but kissed the cash goodbye.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> To assuage the daughter's distress, her mother bought her a new wallet, wrapped it with a Violet Crumble, her favourite confection, then rang her to warn it would be in the mail.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> While they were on the phone, the mother's doorbell rang. The daughter held on while Mum checked.</p><p>You guessed it. It was a package from New York with the daughter's wallet and contents intact.</p><p> There's hope for the human race yet, says Mum.</p><p>COUPLE from Manly in Brisbane were returning from a caravan holiday when hubby said he felt like a break. He pulled into the next rest area and went to lie down in the van.</p><p> His wife heard a terrible crash and found her husband in the throes of a heart attack.</p><p> Unable to drive and without a mobile phone, she ran on to the road and hailed the first car that came.</p><p> It stopped at once, and she found herself talking to her next-door neighbours, who got the patient to hospital pronto.</p><p>THIRTY-YEAR veteran ABC cameraman/sound recordist is throwing a retirement party on Tuesday at the studio's riverside canteen at Toowong. Management, through obviously pursed lips, has decreed that the party must end by 7pm in case people passing on the river should observe undue hilarity at our sober ABC at such an ungodly hour.</p><p>MOVE over, Noel Coward. Arts Minister Matt Foley is noted for spouting poetry at opening events. Last weekend he outdid himself at a Customs House function with an immaculate rendition of Noel Coward's incredibly difficult ditty Nina from Argentina, with all the extravagant gestures Coward used. He brought the house down.</p><p>WHEN Thomas, of Chermside in Brisbane, rang the Family Court to inquire how his application for divorce was progressing, he was put on hold. The music being played: A Fine Romance.</p><p>OUR feature writer Frances Whiting reckons Channel 9 newsreader Jillian Whiting (no relation) has scored one over her. The two are constantly being confused by readers/viewers. You read the news beautifully last night, they tell Frances, and compliment Jillian on her latest feature.</p><p> Last week Jillian was in the Story Bridge Hotel when two polite gentlemen asked if they could buy her a drink. She said yes and they spent a convivial half-hour in conversation. As they left, one bloke said: "I've been very thrilled to meet you. I read your column every week, Frances."</p><p>WOT? A government department that won't take your money? Wilston woman about to go overseas for several months phoned Transport Queensland to arrange to pay her car rego due July 23. No can do, she was told, there won't be an invoice until some days before due date, so we can't accept your money.</p><p> Now she's had to leave cheque and envelope for her sister to post, and wonders how a vast state bureaucracy is unable to cope with such simple situations.</p><p>AFTER the organist resigned from a church in Nottinghamshire, England, the vicar installed a karaoke machine.</p><p>JOKE OF THE WEEK</p><p>A NEWS magazine photographer was assigned to cover a huge forest fire so he asked his office to hire a plane for aerial shots. He was told the plane would be started and waiting for him. Sure enough, a single-engined plane was warming up near the runway at the small, rural airport when he arrived.</p><p>He jumped in with his equipment and yelled: "Let's go! Let's go!" The pilot took off and the photographer told him to make three or four low-level passes over the fire.</p><p>"Why?" asked the pilot. "Because I'm a photographer and photographers take pictures," said the cameraman, impatiently.</p><p>After a long pause, the pilot said: "You mean you're not the instructor?" (From Narelle Stewart of Kenmore).</p><p> *  Send your best joke to win a Mary Ryan's Bookshop $20 voucher for use at its Milton, Paddington or Noosa stores.</p><p>*  Write to Good Mail, The Sunday Mail, GPO Box 130, Brisbane 4001; fax: 3666 6692; <email normalizedValue="mailto:smletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au">smletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email>. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49N3-RN90-01S8-C4ND-00000-00<published>1992-10-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IN BRIEF Train driver was drunk NEW YORK city's worst subway crash which left five dead and more than 200 injured, is now being blamed on the train driver who allegedly had a blood-alcohol reading as high as 0.31. Toxicologist Dr Marina Stajic, of the New York City medical examiner's office, said the driver, Robert Ray, had a blood-alcohol reading three times the legal limit when the train crashed in downtown Manhattan at 12.30am on August 28 last year. Dr Stajic based her assessment on blood taken from Ray and took into account the alcohol he admitted drinking after the crash that left New York City's subway system in disarray for several days. Ray walked away from the crash and later told police he was so upset that he drank four cans of beer. He has denied he was drunk while in control of the train. However, Dr Stajic said even if Ray had four cans of beer after the crash his blood-alcohol reading while at the controls of the train would have been between 0.23 and 0.31. In New York, a person is deemed drunk if they have a reading above 0.1.</p><p>Serbs release 1500 prisoners SERB authorities yesterday released 1500 mostly Muslim prisoners from a detention camp in northern Bosnia-Herzegovina, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said. The operation was intended to empty the Trnopolje camp, one of many camps for Muslims which were set up by the Serbs and provoked international condemnation.</p><p>Earlier reports said all the prisoners were men, but UNHCR spokesman Mr Peter Kessler said he understood there were six women, three girls and 13 boys among them.</p><p>Forest fire out of control A FIRE in California's El Dorado national forest continued to burn out of control yesterday as damage estimates passed $90 million and weary firefighters looked to the weather for help. More than 6596 hectares of forest have been destroyed since the fire began on Tuesday, and state and national forestry officials estimated timber losses and structural damage at $A127 million. At least 27 homes and holiday cabins have been destroyed. The fire continued to move in a north-westerly direction and reached the Union Valley Reservoir, 32 kilometres east of the town of South Lake Tahoe.</p><p>Sounds like a falling star FAILED actor Rick Starr has been singing for his supper on the plaza of Berkeley University in north California for more than a decade. But not very well - in fact his singing is regarded as the worst in America. So bad is his singing that one university staff member working in a third-floor office flanking the plaza has taken Starr to court, charging him with malicious disturbance of the peace. The court battle to remove Starr from the university plaza has sparked debate over whether one person's tastes can dictate whether another person can speak.</p><p>Indians withdraw team INDIA has withdrawn from the world youth netball championships in Suva next month in protest over disparaging comments made by the Prime Minister of Fiji, Mr Sitiveni Rabuka, about the country's Indian community. The team has been barred from flying to Suva by New Delhi as a storm rages over Mr Rabuka's remark which was broadcast on Australian television. Mr Rabuka said he believed all Indians should be repatriated when answering a question on whether it would be better if Fiji's Indians went back to India. Commenting on the interview, screened on Tuesday, Deputy Indian High Commissioner in Canberra, Mr Vidyasagar Verma, said India was not prepared to tolerate the kind of racist remarks made by Mr Rabuka. The team had withdrawn as a protest, he said.</p><p>Mr Rabuka also appeared in the interview to indicate recent promises of change to Fiji's racially-biased constitution were really only made for television.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:47GP-JJ10-015G-Y32Y-00000-00<published>2002-12-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LIFE; Pg. L16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>Mike O'Connor</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">I screamed, smoke billowing from my shorts, and ran through the house, ripping off my daks</p><p nitf:lede="true">I COULD see her eyes peering through the slats of the kitchen blinds as I parked outside the house, sweeping the street like twin radars.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"He's been at it again, has he?" I asked as I walked into the house. "Right outside our house," she nodded, adjusting the blinds to improve her field of vision. "If he does it again I'm going to call the police."</p><p>"Yes," I said. "Do that. I'll be interested to see how long he gets for parking legally in a public street. Twenty years with hard labour I imagine."</p><p>I do as I am told because I am a craven coward. The neighbours do so because they have been sweet-talked into so doing by Herself's considerable diplomatic skills which means they have sworn there will be no loud music, no parties and no conversations conducted above a whisper after 8pm.</p><p>The girl over the road refused to do as she was told and played loud music but, eventually, tired of Herself appearing at her door in night attire and dark glasses asking her to lower the volume, so she moved out.</p><p>As the year draws to a close, Herself could rightly say that she had the street under control, if it wasn't for the one recalcitrant who insists on parking his car in the street outside our house.</p><p>This causes a number of difficulties, the principal one relating to Herself's parking, which has more in common with that required by a 747 jet than a car -- for, like an airline pilot, she lines up her approach to the kerb some distance out from her intended touchdown point.</p><p>Fortunately, we live in a long, straight street which means she can turn into the top of the road, line up the front of our house and then start on her 500m glide path towards the kerb until touchdown outside our house.</p><p>If there's a car parked outside the house, the whole approach is aborted and she leaves the car in the middle of the road until I come home and park it.</p><p>"I'm going to put a note on his windscreen," she said, shutting the blinds. "And what, pray tell, will you write on it it?" I asked. "Mad, neurotic, obsessive people live in this house. Park outside at own risk?"</p><p>"Why don't you give him some of your special mosquito-repelling firesticks?" I said. "That should get rid of him," this being a reference to long sticks coated with an incendiary substance which some fast-talking shopkeeper had convinced her would ward off mosquitoes.</p><p>Last week she lit several and placed them so they protruded from pot plants on the veranda but, unfortunately, failed to advise me of this latest anti-mossie strategy.</p><p>I walked on to the veranda on dusk and seconds later became aware of a burning sensation in my shorts.</p><p>This was no sudden attack of passion. Herself had placed her smouldering anti-mossie sticks at precisely the correct angle at which they were able to slide up the leg of my shorts until making contact with my flesh a centimetre from my reproductive bits whereupon, as red embers met skin, I began to sizzle.</p><p>I screamed, smoke billowing from my shorts, and ran through the house, ripping off my daks.</p><p>"Get out of the bathroom," she yelled as I splashed water on my singed bits and did a quick count. "I've just cleaned the floor. You'll ruin it."</p><p>"Bugger the floor," I yelled. "I've got a forest fire blazing in my crotch!"</p><p>I was lucky to escape with a seared inner thigh and had come uncomfortably close to spending Christmas with a bandaged appendage.</p><p>This, at least, would have afforded it a degree of protection against the whirring blades of fans which, as I recall writing in a column this time last year, pose a significant danger to scantily clad males as, in the depths of the night, they try to negotiate their way through a maze of fans to the bathroom.</p><p>I am reasonably sure that the placement of these fans in the hallway has become part of Herself's strategy to force the installation of airconditioning, her reasoning being that if I collide front on with enough waist-high fans in the night, I'll become sufficiently traumatised to install aircon. Never!</p><p>The smoking fire sticks, then, have been wonderfully effective in keeping me off the veranda but have had no discernible effect on the mosquito population.</p><p>Hark the herald poodle yelps! I think he's just reversed on to an anti-mossie firestick.</p><p>Merry Christmas to all and heartfelt thanks to those people who have supported this column so strongly over the past year. God bless.</p><p><email normalizedValue="mailto:oconnorm@qnp.newsltd.com.au">oconnorm@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:487T-PGN0-015H-D1G4-00000-00<published>2003-03-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Unbalanced debate</p><p nitf:lede="true">WHY do I protest? I believe that debate should include not only opinions but also factual, documented information from all sides, especially when making a decision to go to war.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> I feel the facts that lead us to war are somewhat one-sided.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It is often said that Saddam Hussein is an evil man who must be deposed, especially because of his arsenal of weapons of mass destruction (though UN inspectors' reports contradict this).</p><p nitf:lede="true"> What is not often said is that the US and Britain (and France in the '80s) supported Saddam as an ally throughout major atrocities, helped him develop those weapons and stood by while he waged war against Iran and used gas against the Kurds.</p><p>Since the '50s the US has given aid, military equipment and support to brutal and corrupt regimes and has stood in the way of democratic development in many countries.</p><p> Australian Prime Minister John Howard wants me to support his decision to go to war on flimsy facts and suspect legalities. I think not.</p><p>GRANT BICKERTON, Coolbellup</p><p>Where to next?</p><p>NOW that the allies have bombed Iraq, will they go into North Korea and disarm them? They apparently have MOABs poised to drop on our oh so civilised Western countries.</p><p> And after that will we overthrow Mugabe in Zimbabwe? The answer is no, he only kills his own people, he's no threat to us and his country is a Third World cesspool with no oil.</p><p> Anyway, we play cricket there.</p><p>MANDY SIMMS, Ballajura</p><p>Dividing the spoils</p><p>EVEN before the war in Iraq is over the US Government is letting out tenders for Iraq's reconstruction.</p><p> But only select US companies can apply, all with direct links with the White House, the Republican Party and former members of the US military.</p><p> Having supported US munitions makers in destroying Iraq, the White House will now support its other mates in repairing the damage. It's the closest thing to a perpetual- motion machine ever devised.</p><p>America's wheat farmers must be rapt knowing that the $800 million Iraqi wheat trade in Australian hands is up for grabs.</p><p> Our leaders may support the war and taxpayers may fund it, but when it comes to picking over the carcass we are well down the pecking order.</p><p>ROD ROGERS, Esperance</p><p>Soviets stabilised</p><p>IT seems that only the balancing power of the former Soviet Union ensured a degree of reason in world affairs. Only since the Soviet's demise have we seen such widespread havoc from the Balkans to Afghanistan, from Iraq to Rwanda and Palestine. I am not a communist.</p><p>GEORGE WOOD, White Gum Valley</p><p>Israel not alone</p><p>I DON'T know how old Paul Murray is or to what extent he researches the UN's international rulings, but he has omitted to mention actions against the UN's ruling on the partition of Palestine in 1947 ("With strong, but wrong", TST, March 23).</p><p> Within hours the governments of Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Iraq and Lebanon rejected the UN ruling and vowed to drive the Jews into the sea.</p><p> Even before the British left in 1948, troops from Syria, Jordan and Lebanon were parading through Jerusalem and Haifa. So Israel is not the only offender.</p><p>P. O'NEILL, Perth</p><p>Blazing row</p><p>IN The Sunday Times of March 16 ("Forest fire avoidable -- group"), Forest Alliance spokesman Peter Robertson was quoted as saying that during a recent wildfire CALM firebombed a 6000ha forest block as a part of its burn-off strategy.</p><p> While Mr Robertson may not have noticed, the forest was already burning, and quite comprehensively so.</p><p> Contrary to Mr Robertson's comments, aerial ignition was used as part of a fire-containment strategy.</p><p> He also stated that aerial ignition caused spot fires that burnt out of control. This is not only incorrect but also demonstrates a remarkable ignorance of the dynamics of fire.</p><p> Spot fires that start from 1km to 4km ahead of a fire front originate from a fierce and rapidly running wildfire. Such spot fires do not result from strategically spaced fire lines inserted by aerial ignition.</p><p> If Mr Robertson was not aware of the facts regarding the management and progress of this fire he should have remained silent. If he was aware, then perhaps the Forest Alliance's media releases would be more deserving of an inquiry than CALM's fire management practices.</p><p>TED MIDDLETON, Manjimup</p><p>Highway robbery</p><p>IF the State Government carries out its plan of taking the railway down the Kwinana Fwy and boring a tunnel under our foreshore and CBD it will rob the southern suburbs of their long-promised rail link through Canning Vale, as well as our dedicated bus lanes, which make a trip to the city both pleasurable and efficient.</p><p> It now proposes to rob us of the Fremantle Eastern Bypass and Stage 8 of the Roe Hwy, meaning more traffic on Leach Hwy, High St, South St, Carrington St, Stock Rd and Hampton Rd.</p><p> Can the motive for the sale of the land reserves for these two vital road links be to help pay for the tunnel, which few people want and whose feasibility has yet to be proven, and widening Mt Henry Bridge?</p><p> If so, the citizens of the southern suburbs will be three-time losers.</p><p>J.K. REDDYHOUGH, Willetton</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4135-8160-001Y-344G-00000-00<published>2000-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Part 1 of 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Consolidated Group Results Announcement & Operating Review</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Sydney</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p><br/>HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Consolidated Group Results Announcement & Operating Review<br/>FLETCHER CHALLENGE<br/>CONSOLIDATED GROUP<br/>RESULTS ANNOUNCEMENT AND OPERATING REVIEW<br/>Year ended 30 June 2000<br/>FINANCIAL SUMMARY             Year ended         Year ended<br/>                              June 2000          June 1999<br/>                                NZ$ m              NZ$ m<br/>Operating Revenue                7,908             7,743<br/>Operating Earnings (EBIT)<br/>Including Unusual Items            892               445<br/>Excluding Unusual Items            942               396<br/>Net Earnings<br/>Including Net Unusual Items        382               101<br/>Excluding Net Unusual Items        367               121<br/>Cash Flow from Operations        1,560             1,223<br/>Debt to Total Capitalisation (%)  28.5              35.1<br/>Interest Coverage (times)<br/>Including Net Unusual Items       3.66              2.02<br/>Excluding Net Unusual Items       3.86              1.80<br/>Note: All currency amounts are NZD, unless otherwise stated<br/>FINANCIAL RESULTS<br/>A near four-fold increase in consolidated Group net earnings, to $382<br/>million, has been achieved for the year to June 2000. Net earnings<br/>from continuing operations (excluding the earnings of Fletcher<br/>Challenge Paper sold to Norske Skog on 28 July 2000) were $416<br/>million compared with $95 million in the year to June 1999. Excluding<br/>net unusual items, consolidated Group net earnings were $367 million,<br/>compared with $121 million in the previous year.</p><section sectionType="slug"><bodyText><p>FLC</p></bodyText></section><p><br/>Unusual items, net of taxation and minority interest, amounted to a<br/>gain of $15 million. Major positive contributions were: gains<br/>relating to the sale of Natural Gas Corporation ($113 million),<br/>receipt of the Chilean forest fire insurance proceeds ($11 million),<br/>sale of the turbine marketing rights for the Capstone Turbine<br/>Corporation (S61 million) and the release of a previously<br/>unrecognised taxation benefit following the settlement of the Forests<br/>Distribution In Specie case with the Inland Revenue Department ($93<br/>million).<br/><br/>Major negative unusual items included: a loss on the sale<br/>of the Tasman Eucalypt Forests Estate ($10 million), restructuring<br/>costs relating to the proposed merger of Fletcher Challenge Paper and<br/>Fletcher Challenge Canada ($10 million), costs associated with the<br/>separation of the Fletcher Challenge targeted share structure ($23<br/>million), a write-off following the reorganisation of the Employee<br/>Educational Fund ($116 million), costs associated with the Fletcher<br/>Challenge South American Paper Restructure ($32 million), permanent<br/>impairment relating to Fletcher Challenge Building's Fijian<br/>operations and non-core Fletcher Challenge Energy assets ($30<br/>million), and a write-down in the carrying value of the Central North<br/>Island Forest Partnership ($42 million).<br/><br/>Group operating earnings (EBIT) doubled from $445 million in June<br/>1999 to $892 million in the June 2000 period. Excluding unusual<br/>items, EBIT for the year was $942 million, which represents the best<br/>result for Fletcher Challenge Limited in the past I0 years. EBIT<br/>(excluding unusual items) for the six months to June 2000 was $577<br/>million, a 58 per cent increase on the six months to December 1999.<br/><br/>The ratio of debt to total capitalisation improved significantly from<br/>the 35.1 per cent recorded in June 1999 to 28.5 per cent as free cash<br/>flow was applied to debt reduction, and represents the lowest ratio<br/>the Group has recorded in more than a decade. The ratio of debt to<br/>total capitalisation was also improved by the inclusion in the<br/>revaluation reserve ($730 million) of the 30 June 2000 market value<br/>of Fletcher Challenge's investment in Capstone Turbine Corporation in<br/>accordance with US GAAP. Subsequent to balance date the disposal of<br/>Fletcher Challenge Paper to Norske Skog further reduces the ratio,<br/>based on the 30 June 2000 financial position, to 21.6 per cent.<br/><br/>Interest coverage (operating earnings divided by funding costs)<br/>increased from 2.02 times in June 1999 to 3.66 times this period.<br/><br/>Excluding unusual items, the increase was more than double, to 3.86<br/>times (compared with 1.80 times in June 1999).<br/><br/>THE DIVISIONAL BREAKDOWN OF NET EARNINGS WAS:<br/>EXCLUDING UNUSUAL ITEMS                      INCLUDING UNUSUAL ITEMS<br/>YEAR ENDED   YEAR ENDED                      YEAR ENDED   YEAR ENDED<br/>JUNE 2000    JUNE 1999                       JUNE 2000     JUNE 1999<br/>NZ$ m          NZ$ m                           NZ$ m         NZ$ m<br/>106            72   Fletcher Challenge Building  63            23<br/>162            27   Fletcher ChallengeEnergy    261            55<br/>23             6   Fletcher Challenge Forests   81            55<br/>65             7   Fletcher Challenge Paper    (34)            6<br/>11             9   Consolidation Adjustment     11           (38)<br/>367           121   Total                       382           101<br/>15           (20)   Unusual Items<br/>382           101   Consolidated Net Earnings   382           101<br/>DIVIDENDS<br/>Unless the separation process results in a third party sale<br/>recommendation, the Directors intend that Fletcher Challenge Building<br/>and Fletcher Challenge Energy will declare a final dividend of 8<br/>cents per share and 10 cents per share respectively (record date 29<br/>September 2000). This will bring the total dividend for the year for<br/>Fletcher Building to 16 cents per share (an increase of 33 per cent<br/>over the prior year) and will bring the total dividend for the year<br/>for Fletcher Challenge Energy to 18 cents per share, an increase of<br/>29 per cent. Consistent with past periods, no dividend has been<br/>recommended for Fletcher Challenge Forests.<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">RWECO-FLC3008001110824</dc:identifier><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4135-8160-001Y-344G-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">157560</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="913"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP Company News</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2000 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:49N0-5V20-01S8-C114-00000-00<published>1991-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>CRAWFORD DICK</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Why the man in Tassie's box seat says it's a buzz Brian Poke high in his Watts Hill perch, left, overlooking the North-West's valuable forests . . . "I do it three months of the year because I love it" Tasmania was on full fire alert last week as soaring temperatures hit the State. For one group that meant a particularly important period.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Reporter DICK CRAWFORD and photographer TONY CROSS went in search of the Forestry Commission tower men BRIAN POKE walks 14 km to work each day with his crib in a pack on his back, but slightly eccentric behaviour is said to be par for the course for Forestry Commission tower men.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Brian, who spends a good part of his summer keeping an eagle eye on the North-West's valuable forests from the commission's Watts Hill tower near Nietta, admits it's not a task that appeals to everyone.</p><p>"Tower men are often accused of being crazy," Brian happily admits.</p><p>"But for me it's a buzz.</p><p>"I do it three months of the year because I love it." Having a bird's eye view of awe-inspiring scenery is, for Brian, one of the great attractions of a job he has been doing every summer for the past four years.</p><p>He can see for 100 km in any direction, and on a clear day it is easy to pick out significant geographic landmarks, including Tasmania's tallest mountain, Mt Ossa, to the south.</p><p>Being confined to a three-metre square box perched on top of a 17 metre tower for anything up to 12 hours at a time might not appeal to claustrophobics, but for Brian it's a breeze.</p><p>He keeps contact with the outside world via telephone and solar-powered radio, and in between performing duties, which include hourly weather reports, he passes the time by reading books, going through a series of exercises or just thinking.</p><p>But when the weather starts to heat up and the situation gets "spikey", his tiny radio comes alive with reports being sent in by the commission's network of forest watchers.</p><p>The Watts Hill tower, 1100 metres above sea level, has been a key lookout for the commission since 1955.</p><p>Brian can vouch that it's exposed position means it cops the full blast of any ill winds that hit the North-West.</p><p>On one occasion the tower shuddered as it was hit by a 120 kmh wind.</p><p>The district fire officer for Devonport, Mr Alan Watson, said the number of tower men employed by the commission had decreased but personnel like Brian still played a vital role in forest protection.</p><p>Until 10 years ago the commission relied totally on fire towers, but increasing use was being made of aircraft, Mr Watson said.</p><p>However, while aircraft could cover a big area and accurately locate fires, they could not be kept in the air for long periods.</p><p>"Fire towers give us limited, but continuous coverage," he said.</p><p>Mr Watson said State Government funding cuts had reduced the number of commission employees available to fight fires, and this made early detection vital.</p><p>"It's a matter of setting a balance between an effective fire fighting force and the economies of the State," he said.</p><p>It was likely there would be a shortage of personnel if major fires occurred.</p><p>The commission was reluctant to call in volunteers because of possible legal complications associated with personal injury, and because they did not have specialised training on dealing with forest fires.</p><p>However, there was good co-operation between commission firefighters and rural brigades.</p><p>Devonport's deputy district forester for works, Mr Tony Lade, said an early forest fire detection system was vital.</p><p>"Minutes are important in reducing the damage they (fires) cause," he said.</p><p>The Devonport district had significant pine resources with many trees reaching maturity.</p><p>Fire caused major problems in pine forests.</p><p>Pine killed by fire, unlike eucalypts, had to be salvaged immediately.</p><p>Firebugs are also a concern for the men who protect the State's forests.</p><p>The commission's 1988-89 figures show 36, or 50 per cent, of the State's forest fires were caused by arsonists.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>1) Brian Poke high in his Watts Hill perch overlooking theNorth-West's valuable forests .614.8417032</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49MW-THP0-01S8-C13G-00000-00<published>1991-01-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>MCGUIRK ROD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">38 : Hobart's danger day</p><p nitf:lede="true">Total fire clamp as heatwave hits south</p><p nitf:lede="true">Beating the heat at Sandy Bay are, from front, Shane Allie, 12, of West Hobart, Melissa Brown, 12, of South Hobart, and Nathan Allie, 10, of West Hobart.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By ROD McGUIRK HOBART today faces its biggest fire threat so far this summer and outdoor fires are banned throughout the State.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Volunteer and urban brigades are braced for extreme fire danger in powder-keg conditions in the South-East third of the State, where near-record temperatures are expected.</p><p nitf:lede="true">At greatest risk is the Hobart area, which will reach the top of the fire danger scale if Bureau of Meteorology forecasts late yesterday prove correct.</p><p>The forecast for Hobart is 38 (100.4 on the old scale).</p><p>However, firefighting authorities fear conditions around Hobart will be far more dangerous if winds exceed the moderate 35kmh north-westerlies expected.</p><p>As well, Victoria is expecting its most dangerous day since the 1983 Ash Wednesday tragedy and New South Wales is prepared for a once-in-a-decade bushfire danger.</p><p>The Tasmanian Fire Comissioner, Mr Jim Stewart, said the total fire ban until midnight tonight meant all fire permits were suspended and no open fires allowed.</p><p>The ban also applied to household incinerators and all barbeques except fixed electrical or gas ones.</p><p>Yesterday, fire brigades had a quiet day despite temperatures in Hobart reaching 30 by 2.35pm - 8.5 above the January average.</p><p>Bushy Park recorded the State's maximum of 32 .</p><p>Today's heatwave will be less extreme elsewhere in the State, with Queenstown expecting 32, Launceston 31, and Devonport and Burnie 25.</p><p>Fire fighters are anticipating a high fire risk throughout the rest of the summer.</p><p>The acting Director of Country Brigades, Mr Neil Manning, said scant rainfall since spring had left the countryside dry and well stocked with fuel should a fire break out.</p><p>Victoria has imposed a total fire ban today as the State's heatwave continues.</p><p>About 5000 full-time firefighters from the Department of Conservation and Environment and 75,000 volunteers from the Country Fire Authority are on stand-by with temperatures expected from the low to mid-40s to the 30s across the State.</p><p>About 500 fire trucks and 700 support vehicles and bulldozers, eight aerial water bombers, and six helicopters also are ready.</p><p>In western Victoria yesterday the thermometer hit 43 at Nhill, 42 at Heywood, 41 at Mildura, and just under 40 in Melbourne.</p><p>A top of 42 is predicted for Melbourne today.</p><p>DCE chief fire officer Mr Rod Incoll said the drought conditions throughout the State had turned Victoria into a tinderbox.</p><p>"It's the worst potential fire day since the Ash Wednesday fires of 1983," he said.</p><p>"We will have high temperatures, low humidity, and high winds following a long dry period." In NSW, fire authorities are worried about unusual weather patterns, large amounts of dry vegetation, and an extremely high number of deliberately lit fires.</p><p>A Forestry Commission spokesman said 386 fires were reported in or near State forests from July 1 to December 31 last year.</p><p>Of these, 142 were deliberately lit by unknown people either out of malice or in misguided attempts at controlled burning.</p><p>"These incendiarist fires burned out 23,945 hectares, including 14,078 hectares of State forest - almost half the total State forest fire toll," he said.</p><p>For the first time a one-month total fire ban has been placed on the Kosciusko National Park because of continuing dry weather.</p><p>A NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service spokesman said yesterday the ban would stay unless substantial rain fell across the whole park.</p><p>As well, there are total fire bans on about 55 per cent of NSW for 24 hours from midnight last night.</p><p>A Department of Bush Fire Services spokesman said firefighters were on full alert.</p><p>AAP</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Beating the heat at Sandy Bay are, from front, Shane Allie, 12, of WeHobart, Melissa Brown, 12, of South Hobart, and Nathan Allie, 10, ofWest Hobart.649.1 BEACH AND WATER SCENES7003/7</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source
