urn:contentItem:4CN5-15M0-015G-Y3WF-00000-00<published>2004-06-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LIFE; Pg. L02</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>Compiled by Lisa Yallamas</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SKIES ABLAZE</p><p nitf:lede="true">EXPLOSIVE artists will lash the skies above Surfers Paradise tonight as the first act of the national fireworks championships bombards the night to the sounds of a live, nine-piece band. The colours of acts two and three will blaze over the seaside skies on June 26 and July 3. 7.30pm-9pm.</p><p nitf:lede="true">CARTOON ART</p><p nitf:lede="true">CARTOONIST Michael Leunig opens a retrospective of work by Melbourne artist Mirka Mora at the Noosa Regional Art Gallery today at 2pm. Tomorrow, cartoonist Bruce Petty will give an illustrated talk on the art of drawing at a gallery barbecue at 12.30pm. Mora will talk at noon. Pelican St, Tewantin. Ph: (07) 5449 5340</p><p>MINI ART</p><p>ART for ants -- 1mm x 1.2mm. Bring a magnifying glass to the free Sunday at the Gallery miniatures workshop with artist Gareth Donnelly, 2pm-4pm. Over at the Museum of Brisbane at 2pm tomorrow is a talk by an academic and an architect on Brisbane Architecture, Brisbane City Hall.</p><p>WALK FOR KIDS</p><p>CELEBRATE good health and raise money for the Mater Children's Hospital tomorrow by walking 5km. The Mater 5K for Kids starts</p><p>at 9am at the South Bank cultural forecourt, $10.</p><p>BUSH CRAFT</p><p>THE secrets of calming an injured possum will be revealed today at the Bush Rescue with Friends of Downfall Creek Bushland Centre. Starts 9am. Ph: 3865 5187. Tomorrow join a BCC ranger to learn about forest fire management -- meet at Douglas St, Brighton, next to Nashville Primary School, Deagon and Third Lagoon Wetlands. Free.</p><p>BIG GIG CARNIVALE</p><p>CHARIOT racing, sideshow alley, hot rods and mini-trotting at Albion Park Raceway's Big Gig Carnivale today 4.30pm-11pm and tomorrow, 10am-4pm. Free courtesy buses from Brunswick St train station. This morning, the police will check the speed of your throwing arm at Virginia State School's fete from 11am. Tug of war at 2pm, pony rides, animal farm, coin toss, putt putt, bands and choirs, clowns and rides. Live band, TC & The Gurlz, at 4pm. 1678 Sandgate Rd, Virginia. Or enjoy a stroll through an old-fashioned church fete in beautiful Gregory Park today, (8am-1pm) Baroona Rd, Milton. The inner-western suburbs church fete has home-baked goodies, trash 'n' treasure and plants.</p><p>RALLY FOR REFUGEES</p><p>SOMEONE named after Camelot's wizard blindsides Big Brother . . . it doesn't get much better. Did Merlin Luck's silent protest on last week's Big Brother eviction night achieve anything? The media coverage of the Human Rights Commissioner Dr Sev Ozdowksi's speech at today's World Refugee Day rally in King George Square at 11am is not likely to match the prime time exposure of "the Merlin incident".</p><p>Tomorrow, several bands are playing at the Place To Call Home concert, including the Daisycutters, pictured, and Shutterspeed at Souths Leagues club, West End, 5pm.</p><p>TRAIN BUFFS</p><p>TOP times for train enthusiasts with the Toowoomba Model Train Exhibition, at the Toowoomba Showgrounds, Glenvale Rd, Toowoomba, $6-$4. Miniature train rides. ph: 07 4638 1408 or 07 4632 7523. Today 9am-5pm. Tomorrow 9am-4pm. And Ipswich's Workshops Rail Museum has school holiday Harry Potter madness with Harry's movies at 10am and 1pm daily from next Saturday to July 12. Storytelling hourly 10am-4pm. $16-$9, North St, North Ipswich. ph: 3432 5196.</p><p>BRAIN STORMS</p><p>SYNAPTIC gymnastics (in anything from reading to sport) becomes perfunctory unless you occasionally nudge the brain's electrical impulses into unknown territory -- and much of the brain is uncharted territory. So the Fellowship of Australian Writers are crossing art forms in Synaptic Graffiti, a blend of poetry, art, music, digital and live performance. Today in the Brisbane City Council Main City Library theatrette, City Plaza, Adelaide St, City, 3pm, $3.</p><p>TEDDY BEARS REPAIRING HEARTS</p><p>TEDDY bears are like cardiac specialists, they repair little broken hearts. So it is appropriate that their conference at this weekend's Winter Wonderland Doll and Bear Show at City Hall will benefit research into children's heart defects at the Prince Charles Hospital. Hundreds of bears and dolls are for sale. Free valuations of senior bears and dolls. 9.30am-4pm today and 9.30am-3.30pm tomorrow.</p><p>And coming soon . . .</p><p>BUGS GALORE</p><p>GRANDPARENTS, or great aunts and uncles, might want to go exploring with youngsters aged four to 12 at the Downfall Creek Bushland Centre for bugs -- yes, Bugs Galore is on the Gold 'n' Kids program. Games, crafts and guided walk at 10am, June 29. $5.50. Ph: 3865 5187.</p><p> *  Kids Big Art Day Out at the Noosa Regional Gallery next Saturday. 10am-3pm. Doll making, entertainment and stalls. Pelican St Tewantin Ph: (07) 5449 5340.</p><p>KIDS' PANTOMIME</p><p>HOLIDAY pantomime Bagged is about the after-hours antics inside Timothy's Toyshop. June 26 and 27, July 3, 4, 10, 11, $6. Hands On Art, The Boardwalk South Bank. ph: 3844 4589.</p><p>ACTION WOMEN</p><p>FANCY yourself a Moon Maiden and a Real Adventure Woman? Join Queensland Canoeing for a moonlight paddle at Shorncliffe on July 2, 8pm-10pm. $50. Ph: 3278 1033. The BCC's RAW program has a sailing canoe adventure at Coochiemudlo Island tomorrow at 9am (same July 11). Sail on a Polynesian canoe that uses paddle and sail power, $98 includes transfers from CBD and refreshments. Ph: 1300 305 894.</p><p>EXPLORE WETLANDS</p><p>EXPLORE the Tinchi Tamba wetlands at Bald Hills by canoe with a Brisbane City Council ranger on July 4, 9am to noon, $30. Bookings: 3403 8888.</p><p> Free wetlands discovery bike hike with Brisbane City Council ranger through the Kedron/Boondall bikeway on July 18, 9am-11am. Bookings: 3403 8888.</p><p>Got an event coming up? Fax your information to (07) 3666 6690 or e-mail Lisa Yallamas on <email normalizedValue="mailto:yallamasl@qnp.newsltd.com.au">yallamasl@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p><p>EDITOR: Des Houghton, 1300 30 40 20, <email normalizedValue="mailto:houghtond@qnp.newsltd.com.au">houghtond@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p><p>EDITORIAL INQUIRIES: 3666 6338 or 3666 6286</p><p>LETTERS: GPO Box 130, Brisbane 4001</p><p>ADVERTISING: Tony Redwood 3666 6117</p><p>DESIGN: Jason Nahrung</p><p>PRODUCTION: Colin Wood</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:585M-B8C1-F0NH-V23V-00000-00<published>2013-04-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LETTERS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A 'clean' fireplace plea</p><p nitf:lede="true">WITH winter knocking on everyone's door and the increasing cost of just trying to survive I urge everyone with fireplaces, please do not burn green wood and certainly not treated timber as I have heard done in the past.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Someone who burned treated timber, when questioned, responded: "I don't smell it, it goes straight up chimney". Yeah, thanks mate: leave it for everyone else to inhale the toxins and choke our lungs - not to mention the animals, environment and poor asthmatics.</p><p nitf:lede="true">I have nothing against fireplaces but please just be considerate of what gets put into them, and of others that choose to live in a beautiful part of Australia, that being Narooma "a healthy little town".</p><p nitf:lede="true">Dan Borg</p><p>Narooma</p><p>D??j?? vu again?</p><p>I AM an old, part-time muso and among the original supporters of our music festival, right from the sound of that first 'amped up' kick drum at the old leisure centre. It's a long story and everybody knows it.</p><p>We reluctantly lost our gig after years of community support. I think it was along the lines of, business decision, sorry boys, cop it sweet.</p><p>That now seems to have morphed into being excited about a spiritual return home. As they say in the city: 'time to move on'.</p><p>Al Heffernan</p><p>Narooma</p><p>Tourists the target</p><p>WELL another week, another anti-HuntFest rant by the persistent Susan Cruttenden. I wish the Lotto numbers were as predictable!</p><p>Working on the theory that empty vessels make the most noise, I seldom write to the News, unlike Ms Cruttenden and others of her ilk, but I think in the interests of balancing public perceptions it is time to correct a few fallacies being promoted by the emerald green militia.</p><p>Will there be firearms at HuntFest? No! Will there be ammunition at HuntFest? No! Will there be even a whiff of cordite in our sea-kissed air on the June long weekend? No!</p><p>What there will be, hopefully, are a few hundred tourists, who may spend a couple of hours at the sports and leisure centre looking at the various photographic exhibits, camping gear, bushwalking and hunting paraphernalia, venison sausages, ATV displays, etc.</p><p>But they will materialise only if the rabid few don't turn them off our town beforehand, with tales of gun-totin' madmen running rampant down Bluewater Drive and shootin' up the Inlet!</p><p>It is hoped that these same tourists will go some way to filling the local motels, van parks, restaurants, take-aways and fishing outlets after spending a little time at HuntFest itself; that perhaps they will engage a fishing charter, play a round of golf or tour the coast and hinterland, spending time (and dollars) at local businesses.</p><p>Mid-winter is not the busiest time of year in a south coast town - heaven knows that if one did wish to fire a cannon through town in June, the chances of hitting anyone would be remote! So instead of bitterly opposing a would-be attraction like HuntFest, isn't it time that local people either got behind it, or shut up and showed at least some tolerance for those who are trying to do something positive for local businesses?</p><p>Personally, I haven't shot anything (let alone anyone!) for some years, but I reserve the right to participate in the sport - or support those who do their bit to rid the countryside of feral vermin.</p><p>But that said, HuntFest is not itself related to shooting in national parks, state forests or anywhere else. It is quite simply an attempt to attract visitors here and as such is no better or worse than the Oyster or Blues Festivals or the local show. So come on, people, show some moderation and common sense about this, and remember that being critical is easy; being creative is so much harder!</p><p>Stuart Kennedy</p><p>Corunna</p><p>Mayor's column: Tilba tops for tourism</p><p>WE may be looking at a Tilba-led tourism economic recovery with all the celebrities seen recently at the Tilba Easter Festival! Paul West, the new presenter for the River Cottage foodie show which is being filmed in Tilba now, was cooking up local produce to an admiring crowd while Rob Palmer, DIY presenter on the Better Homes and Gardens show was spotted buying lollies at the Lolly Shop.</p><p>Word of mouth is still one of the best ways to get the story out to potential visitors about the Eurobodalla and if the word is coming from a TV celebrity, then all the better.</p><p>My congratulations and genuine thanks to the hard working volunteers who make the annual Easter festival happen.</p><p>Streetscape project</p><p>Community involvement in the Narooma streetscape project has been excellent with 191 people completing the survey and sharing their thoughts and ideas about the landscaping plan for the Narooma flat area. </p><p>Council engineers have also met with students from Narooma Primary School and council's youth committee to ask for their ideas and I heard the kids gave excellent feedback. We felt it was important to have young people involved as the landscape plans we finish up with will develop and grow in their lifetime and they will be able to proudly say, I helped make this happen.</p><p>New cycling event</p><p>As a bit of a cycling enthusiast myself, I was delighted to hear we secured another cycling event for Batemans Bay. The Bicycle NSW Discovery Weekend which attracts around 500 riders will be held in Batemans Bay in late November.</p><p>Not only will these groups stay and play in Eurobodalla for the weekend, we can expect that once many of these first-time visitors find out what's on offer here, they will be motivated to return with family and friends. The event will attract widespread media coverage, and raise Eurobodalla's profile as an excellent cycling destination.</p><p>Staff relay for life</p><p>A few weeks ago I congratulated council staff for raising more than $3000 in the Cancer Council's Relay for Life. I was wrong ' they raised $9673!</p><p>This was a fantastic effort by all the staff involved.</p><p>While everyone deserves a big pat on the back, special mention must go Mike Clements, council's WHS advisor who not only was the driving force for council getting involved, but was also was an organising committee member for the event. Mike spent most of the weekend from 5.00am on the Saturday through to Sunday afternoon at the venue.</p><p>The 514 participants in 47 teams in this year's Eurobodalla Relay for Life raised a total of $99,990.11. Well done to everyone.</p><p>Lindsay Brown, Eurobodalla Mayor</p><p>Earn and Learn is back</p><p>NAROOMA primary school students recently had delivered over $16,000 worth of resources, the result of a hugely successful 2012 Earn and Learn promotion by Woolworths.</p><p>The dedication of the students, their families and friends earned the school in excess of 206,000 sticker points. The resources we received - books, maths equipment, construction kits, visual art supplies, special percussion instruments and outdoor play equipment - are now being enjoyed by the children from Kindergarten to Year 6, both inside and outside the classrooms.</p><p>I would once again encourage all community members to support our local schools and preschools by requesting your sticker entitlements each time you pass through the checkout throughout this year's Earn Learn promotion.</p><p>If placing stickers on the card is too fiddly, just drop the stickers into the chosen box, as we have many helpers happy to do the sticking for you. There are not a lot of opportunities in small towns like ours to fundraise for our schools, so by supporting Earn and Learn you are using your weekly shopping dollars to provide resources at no extra cost to you.</p><p>I sincerely hope we can all get on board and achieve another outstanding effort for the students in Narooma and surrounds this year. Thank you in anticipation of your support.</p><p>Jo Millar</p><p>Narooma Primary</p><p>E and L co-ordinator</p><p>Replace lost parking</p><p>I DRAW your readers' attention to the landscape design survey for the Narooma streetscape project in Bluewater Drive. Submissions close this Friday.</p><p>The realignment of Bluewater Drive and its associated works have removed informal parking for probably 40-50 cars beside NATA oval. That area has been vital for holding functions in the centre, at the pool or on the oval itself.</p><p>Surprisingly the design as it is at the moment makes no provision to replace this lost car parking.</p><p>I feel it is really important for the future function and viability of the precinct encompassing NATA oval, the swimming pool, the sport and leisure centre and even the town wharf that the enlarged area created beside the centre by the realignment be used for informal car parking - on grass, not sealed, so that it is green space when not needed as overflow parking.</p><p>That's the area beside the centre on the corner of Bluewater Drive and the Highway. </p><p>While it is all very nice to consider creating an additional picnic area, or cafe and alfresco use, or new playground, in this area as listed in the survey, my concern is that without replacing the lost informal parking in this precinct we will effectively sterilise this area for future activities.</p><p>Laurelle Pacey</p><p>Narooma</p><p>Extreme weather report a wake-up call: CEFE</p><p>THE latest report from the Climate Commission on extreme weather should be a wake-up call for those living in the South East. The report, called 'The Critical Decade: Extreme weather' was released on April 3 and can be found at climatecommission.gov.au.</p><p>I suggest anyone interested in the future of our region should take a look at it.</p><p>According to the report, climate change is already increasing the intensity and frequency of many extreme weather events. The summer of 2012/13 was the hottest on record and included the hottest sea surface temperatures on record for the Australian region for January and February.</p><p>All-time high maximum temperatures were measured at 44 weather stations across the country.</p><p>Over the period 1971-2008, the duration and frequency of heatwaves have increased, and the hottest days during a heatwave have become even hotter.</p><p>Over 2010-2011, every state and territory had sites that set all-time rainfall records. Across Australia, it is more likely than not, that heavy rainfall events will become more frequent as the temperature increases.</p><p>For southeast Australia, nearly all of the climate models used in a recent analysis project a significant increase in drought by the end of the century.</p><p>The Forest Fire Danger Index, one of the measures of bushfire threat, has increased significantly in Australia. The increase has been most prominent in southeast Australia, and has been manifest as a longer duration fire season, with fire weather extending into November and March.</p><p>A sea-level rise of 0.5 m (compared to 1990), which lies near the lower end of the estimates for 2100, leads to surprisingly large impacts. For coastal areas a sea-level rise of 0.5 m would lead to very large increases in the incidence of extreme events, typically by a factor of several hundred and in some places by as much as one thousand.</p><p>An ever-increasing level of atmospheric CO2 is giving weather systems a shot of adrenaline.</p><p>We are going to have to strengthen our Rural Fire Service and prepare communities for more frequent catastrophic bushfire events.</p><p>We will have to change agricultural practices to cope with longer and more severe droughts, and we'll have to start coping with more severe rainfall events and flooding.</p><p>We will have to get smarter about water storage. We are going to have to plan for sea level rise, and work out how to absorb the huge cost of coastal inundation. We are going to have to adapt to changing fisheries. We will have to come up with strategies to protect the elderly from heat waves, and we will have to adapt to changing patterns of infectious and vector borne diseases. We are going to have to build a stronger sense of community resilience, and we going to have to stop looking for excuses.</p><p>Above all we are going to have to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels, and we need to do it quickly.</p><p>Only strong preventive action now can stabilise the climate and slow the trend of increasing extreme weather for our children. We need strong leadership from politicians who are prepared to stand up and face the challenge of climate change.</p><p>Matthew Nott</p><p><url normalizedValue="http://www.cleanenergyforeternity.net.au">www.cleanenergyforeternity.net.au</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">NARONW-1421870</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">NARONW2013</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:585M-B8C1-F0NH-V23V-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">390610</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-10-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="2009"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2013 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. urn:contentItem:49MW-TJP0-01S8-C0YS-00000-00<published>1991-04-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">What's next?</p><p nitf:lede="true">We've suffered the Tasmania Bank fiasco/sweetheart deal with no public inquiry; the political bribe scandal; the police advertising "defend us or defend yourself" (and if we choose to defend ourselves we end up in court); the miners on the West Coast and King Island being shafted; Pam Clarke's chooks still in the pen; Neil Robson to depart the political scene and failing in his dream of recreating the Shannon Rise; SeaCat Tasmania plagued with problems every other week; a sawmiller suggesting (on national TV) that greenies be incinerated in the forest; our fish resources being plundered by non-Tasmanian vessels; Bennett and Evers resigning because the money wasn't good enough; Groom stepping down from Deputy Leader of the Opposition because his opposition was his leader; Weldon's Latin/HEC folly; Jackson's "we will not budge on the school bus fares u-turn"; the extermination of Grassy; the shop trading saga; EZ's dump it on the tip and cadmium capers; the petrol "on again, off again" roster system; the shut shops tour for cruise ship passengers; gun laws being debated while M16 select-fire weapons were being advertised through The Mercury; landslip hassles and the homeless still "living" on the streets.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Yet to come we have forest resource (we'll bring you down) legislation and, God forbid, Michael "The Mouth from the South, I will return" Hodgman seeking the more prestigous role of MHA.</p><p>Me? I'm just a voter, but I've had enough. So how about it people?</p><p>How about giving up 10 seconds and the cost of a stamp to write the message, "I've had enough" and address it to the Governor.</p><p>DAVID W. ROBERTS Snug Challenge When Premier Field broke the Accord last year, despite Mercury Editorial counsel against doing so, he knew he was also removing the Accord's constraints on the use of no-confidence motions.</p><p>The Greens had accepted those constraints in return for Labor delivering the specified package of environmental safeguards, democratic reforms and social justice policies.</p><p>He had at least a week to think out the consequences. He chose deliberately the option which was the road to instability.</p><p>It is ironic that the Premier's unilateral decision to bust the Accord's woodchip quota ceiling has led directly to the potential no-confidence motion against resource security legislation in which he would expand the powers of the Legislative Council and further bind the hands of future popularly-elected governments.</p><p>The Mercury's comment now that the Greens' "uncompromising attitude doomed the Accord" sits ill-at-ease with its assertion then that "as much as the State Government and some of its spokesmen may attempt to fudge around the issue, the Accord it signed with the Green independents clearly precludes any increase in the woodchip quota".</p><p>Mr Field depends for his authority on every one of his ALP and Green colleagues. He is not a law unto himself. Authority comes in no small measure from keeping commitments made to colleagues. If he wishes to restore the Accord and renew his faithfulness to its provisions, below which he placed his signature in May 1989, then the Greens will immediately resume the constraints on "no-confidence" motions. How about that Premier Field?</p><p>(Dr) BOB BROWN, MHA Hobart Forest facts Recent Letters from the Wilderness Society continue to ignore the facts on forestry funding.</p><p>For more than four decades previous Tasmanian governments directly supported rurally based forest industries to promote employment and wealth creation. In addition, the Forestry Commission has been directed to assist community support-type activities such as unemployment relief.</p><p>Most sectors of the economy - agriculture, fishing, manufacturing and, more recently, tourism, have received government support.</p><p>Rather than tariffs, marketing schemes, advertising assistance and direct tax subsidies, the forestry sector has specifically received concessional royalties. However, to continue the sound environmental policy of reforesting harvested areas and protecting them for future generations, the Forestry Commission was required by government to directly borrow funds to cover the difference between expenditure for forest protection and royalty income.</p><p>Loans for investment in State forest management were taken out.</p><p>These have been invested in real assets which include tens of thousands of hectares of regenerated forests, large areas of plantations, roads, bridges, recreational facilities, forest fire protection measures and a substantial body of ecological and forest management research.</p><p>To put the Forestry Commission on a more commercial basis, the State Government has: Transferred the past loan investments into State Government equity in the public forests.</p><p>Required the Forestry Commission to balance revenue and expenditure and pay a dividend to the State annually.</p><p>Ensured that non-commercial activities - recreational and other public facilities, some fire protection measures, etc - are funded by a direct grant from government and these funds are reported separately in annual reports to parliament.</p><p>Introduced pricing and timber allocation reforms to secure a fairer direct return to the State from timber sales.</p><p>In 1988/89 and 1989/90 the Forestry Commission made a net operating surplus of $10.9 million and $6.3 million. This provides for a direct financial contribution to the State.</p><p>Major commercial changes have been made and are continuing to be implemented in public forestry. Critics are welcome to come to the Forestry Commission office and meet the staff involved and be fully briefed. Sadly, none of the authors of recent criticisms have taken the time to do this.</p><p>EVAN R. ROLLEY Chief Commissioner Forestry Commission</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4582-1DS0-0197-F12F-00000-00<published>1996-10-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">Awakening the herd THE recent outcry by Pauline Hanson reflects the</p><p nitf:lede="true">paranoia of Professor Geoffrey Blainey, Bruce Ruxton and Ron Casey who</p><p nitf:lede="true">targeted Asians in the early 1980s.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Hanson has caused the nation to split rather than promoting</p><p nitf:lede="true">harmony. All immigrants here have accepted English as the official</p><p nitf:lede="true">language. To demand that there should be only ""one language" and one</p><p nitf:lede="true">flag in Australia reflects the superficial mentality and</p><p nitf:lede="true">near-sightedness of a poorly educated politician who would do less harm</p><p nitf:lede="true">in a fish and chip shop.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>I also am disappointed with the herd mentality of those who gave</p><p>her a standing ovation after her speech at the National Party's</p><p>Mansfield branch meeting. No other democratic country in the world</p><p>would put forth such a demand._ Dr I. Lim, Toowoomba.</p><p>October 2</p><p>WE have come a long way from the beer halls of Munich to the fish and</p><p>chip shops of Ipswich but Pauline Hanson's ""one people, one nation,</p><p>one flag" utterances to the Mansfield National Party branch meeting</p><p>are not exactly new concepts. But they are tried and true methods to</p><p>rally nationalist fervour.</p><p>""Ein volk, ein Reich, ein Fuehrer" worked well for one budding</p><p>politician earlier this century but if anyone starts talking about</p><p>""Liebenstraum" I'm going to pack my bags quick smart._ Tony Ashworth,</p><p>Sunnybank Hills.</p><p>October 4</p><p>No win, no findings THE article ""Sacked pub staff have a win" (C-M,</p><p>Oct 2) is quite misleading. The Anti-Discrimination Tribunal made no</p><p>findings in the matter, including any findings as to whether the three</p><p>women complainants had been discriminated against or sacked (by former</p><p>pub manager Gordpn Campbell) or whether they had been called what they</p><p>said they were called.</p><p>There was certainly no ""ruling of the Commission", as is</p><p>suggested by one of the women, Lynette Quilliam.</p><p>Journalists were present throughout the proceedings in which all</p><p>the evidence was never completed. The journalist has chosen to report</p><p>what might make a story, where it should have been clearly reported</p><p>that no findings were made.</p><p>In its attempts to have a distorted inference drawn, the article is</p><p>also unbalanced. It reports the evidence of the complainants almost to</p><p>the total exclusion of the evidence of the respondent to which it</p><p>devoted only three lines.</p><p>As well as the respondent's denials, the allegations made against</p><p>him also were consistently denied by five witnesses, all employees of</p><p>the hotel and all of whom were vigorously cross-examined by the women's</p><p>counsel._ Nita Stratton-Funk (solicitor for Gordon Campbell), Brisbane.</p><p>October 3</p><p>Managing smoke S.M. STARKEY'S article ""Smoke gets in your eyes"</p><p>(Perspectives, Sept 28) inaccurately summarises forest fire management</p><p>practices in Queensland.</p><p>In conjunction with the Department of Natural Resources, DPI</p><p>Forestry relies on a system of firebreaks, annual controlled burning,</p><p>vigilant surveillance and rapid suppression to prevent or control</p><p>wildfires. In controlled burning, the skilful application of fire to</p><p>forests reduces plant litter and debris from the forest floor, which</p><p>fuel wild fires, while maintaining a protective mulch to prevent soil</p><p>erosion and preserve soil moisture.</p><p>DPI Forestry also has a policy on smoke management to minimise the</p><p>impact of smoke on the visual amenity of rural and urban areas,</p><p>community health and traffic safety. This involves careful</p><p>consideration of weather conditions and ensuring controlled burning</p><p>takes place in the minimum amount of time._ T. E. Just, acting</p><p>executive director (Forestry), DPI Queensland, Brisbane.</p><p>October 2</p><p>Let the law apply THE sexual abuse of children must not be condoned,</p><p>but neither must journalistic irresponsibility.</p><p>You reported on the front page (C-M, Sept 28) that allegations</p><p>against Fr Ron McKiernan were being investigated. But, inside the</p><p>paper, was an article (Monitor) which clearly assumed the accusations</p><p>were true. If someone (especially a priest or a religious) is accused</p><p>of sexual misconduct, that seems to be sufficient for the media to find</p><p>him guilty as charged. The same logic was used by the witch-hunters of</p><p>Salem, Massachusetts.</p><p>I wonder what would happen if a journalist or a newspaper</p><p>proprietor were accused of misconduct. I wonder what the media would</p><p>say. Would they say anything?</p><p>If Fr McKiernan is guilty, let the law take its course, but let it</p><p>be the law of a civilised and intelligent society, not the lynch law of</p><p>sensation-mongers._ A. W. Sparkes, Redcliffe.</p><p>September 29</p><p>Rhetoric doesn't count THE State Government's stated view that the</p><p>environment is more important than tourism and should be protected from</p><p>being ""loved to death" is commendable; its idea of private companies</p><p>buying and managing land for conservation is exciting but the concept</p><p>of free enterprise in national parks is positively frightening.</p><p>The proposed resort and marina site being excavated on the</p><p>Hinchinbrook Channel will accommodate more people than the nearby town</p><p>of Cardwell.</p><p>The Government has told us that its research (with narrow terms of</p><p>reference) assures that no adverse impacts will occur in this highly</p><p>environmentally sensitive area. Despite more than 150 scientists'</p><p>objections to the development and ongoing protests and petitions, the</p><p>project continues.</p><p>Platitudes and rhetoric don't count</p><p>for much when everyone can see what is happening in practice. If</p><p>the Government wants some credibility, it should stop this project</p><p>before any more costly damage is done._ G. A. Reed, Indooroopilly.</p><p>October 2</p><p>Clock on shoppers CONSUMERS and small business do not want or require</p><p>extended trading hours. Let's learn from the mistakes of the other</p><p>states.</p><p>Consumers are constantly told that to manage their affairs they</p><p>should make a weekly budget _ the answer to everything.</p><p>We have certain funds to spend each week and because shops are open</p><p>longer, it does not mean we will have more money to spend. It does mean</p><p>goods will cost more once the small trader no longer exists and the</p><p>element of competition is gone.</p><p>Sir William Knox felt the Government should make available more</p><p>information and courses for the small trader to help in the management</p><p>of their business. This will not assist the majority of traders who are</p><p>hurting; we are family businesses, not idiots who need training.</p><p>It seem to be men who make these decisions. It would be interesting</p><p>to know if any of them shop after</p><p>6pm in supermarkets, or would they?_ Pat Higgins, Bowen Hills.</p><p>October 3</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Report</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Sydney</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p><br/>HOMEX - Sydney<br/>-------------------------<br/>Half Yearly Report<br/>CONSOLIDATED GROUP<br/>RESULTS ANNOUNCEMENT AND OPERATING REVIEW<br/>SIX MONTHS ENDED 31 DECEMBER 1999<br/>FINANCIAL HIGHLIGHTS<br/>                                SIX MTHS    SIX MTHS     SIX MTHS<br/>                                DEC 1999    JUN 1999     DEC 1998<br/>                                    NZ$M        NZ$M         NZ$M<br/>Operating Revenue                  3,812       3,651        4,092<br/>Operating Earnings (EBIT)<br/>Including Unusual Items             455         131          314<br/>Excluding Unusual Items             365         138          258<br/>Net Earnings<br/>Including Unusual Items             239         (12)         113<br/>Excluding Unusual Items             135          34           87<br/>Cash Flow from Operations            690         527          696<br/>Debt to Total Capitalisation %      32.3        35.1         36.7<br/>Interest Coverage (times)<br/>Including Unusual Items            3.79        1.34         2.57<br/>Excluding Unusual Items            3.04        1.41         2.11<br/>Note: All currency amounts are NZD, unless otherwise stated<br/>GROUP RESULTS<br/>The financial results for the consolidated Fletcher Challenge Group<br/>for the December half-year were substantially ahead of those achieved<br/>in both the six month periods to June 1999 and December 1998.<br/><br/>Consolidated Group net earnings, at $239 million, were up 112 per<br/>cent on the $113 million recorded in the corresponding period to<br/>December 1998, and represent a significant turnaround from the loss<br/>of $12 million reported in the six months period to June 1999.<br/><br/>Unusual items, net of taxation and minority interests, in the latest<br/>period comprised: a gain of $113 million on the sale of Natural Gas<br/>Corporation, a loss of $10 million on the sale of the Tasman eucalypt<br/>forest estate, a gain of $11 million relating to the receipt of Chile<br/>forest fire insurance proceeds, and restructuring costs of $10<br/>million relating to direct costs associated with the proposed merger<br/>of Fletcher Challenge Paper and Fletcher Challenge Canada.</p><section sectionType="slug"><bodyText><p>FLC</p></bodyText></section><p><br/>Excluding net unusual items, net earnings were $135 million, compared<br/>with $34 million and $87 million for the two immediate preceding<br/>six-month periods.<br/><br/>Operating earnings (EBIT) excluding unusual items rose from $138<br/>million in the June 1999 half year, to $365 million in this period -<br/>a 164 per cent improvement, and a $107 million increase over the $258<br/>million reported in December 1998.<br/><br/>Cash flow from operations was up 31 per cent on the $527 million in<br/>the June 1999 half-year to $690 million, in line with the $696<br/>million in the December 1998 period.<br/><br/>The ratio of debt to total capitalisation improved even further from<br/>the 36.7 per cent recorded in December 1998, to 32.3 per cent, and<br/>represents the lowest ratio the Group has recorded in more than a<br/>decade. This improvement was also reflected in the ratio of the cash<br/>flow coverage of interest, which increased from 3.79 times in the<br/>June 1999 half-year to 4.63 times this period.<br/><br/>As a result of the overall financial performance improvement and<br/>favourable business outlook, dividend increases for Building and<br/>Energy have been announced. Building has increased its interim<br/>dividend by 33 per cent, from 6.0 cents to 8.0 cents per share.<br/><br/>Energy shareholders will receive a 1.0 cent (14 per cent) increase to<br/>8.0 cents per share. Given the current Paper separation process,<br/>Directors have decided to hold the current level of dividend for<br/>Paper shareholders at 1.5 cents per share. Consistent with past<br/>periods, Forests has not declared a dividend. All dividends will be<br/>fully tax credited.<br/><br/>The divisional breakdown of net earnings was:<br/>EXCLUDING UNUSUAL ITEMS                     INCLUDING UNUSUAL ITEMS<br/>6 MTHS    6 MTHS    6 MTHS                  6 MTHS    6 MTHS    6 MTHS<br/>DEC 99    JUN 99    DEC 98                  DEC 99    JUN 99    DEC 98<br/>NZ$M      NZ$M      NZ$M    DIVISION        NZ$M       NZ$M      NZ$M<br/>46         55        17     Building         46         6        17<br/>61        (13)       40     Energy          174        (1)       56<br/>  4          3         3     Forests          15        52         3<br/>18        (11)       18     Paper            (2)      (22)       28<br/>  6                    9     Consoli-          6       (47)        9<br/>                             dation<br/>                             Adjustment<br/>135         34        87     Total           239       (12)      113<br/>104        (46)       26     Unusuals<br/>239        (12)      113     Consolidated    239       (12)      113<br/>                             Net Earnings<br/>OPERATING PERFORMANCE<br/>Detailed reports on operations and results are contained in the<br/>separate announcements for each of the four divisions.<br/><br/>Fletcher Challenge Building (FCB) achieved a strong result, with net<br/>earnings of $46 million, up 171 per cent on the $17 million reported<br/>in the previous corresponding period. The result reflected a doubling<br/>in earnings from operations ($81 million, compared to $40 million in<br/>the previous corresponding period) and $8 million of restructuring<br/>costs incurred in relation to the downsizing of international<br/>construction operations, exiting the Chinese steel operations, and<br/>the sale of Fletcher Aluminium's Hamilton production facility.<br/><br/>Domestic businesses continued to benefit from the strong upturn in<br/>residential construction activity that commenced early in the<br/>calendar year. Most businesses experienced higher demand, but price<br/>competition was intense in readymix concrete, concrete pipes and<br/>steel. Earnings were assisted by ongoing benefits from cost reduction<br/>and productivity improvement programmes.<br/><br/>Net earnings (excluding unusual items) of Fletcher Challenge Energy<br/>(FCE) rose 53 per cent to $61 million. Both production and price<br/>increases were achieved in nearly all of the key businesses. Gas<br/>production in New Zealand increased by 15.5 per cent to 66.2 billion<br/>cubic feet (bcf) reflecting higher demand from the methanol and<br/>thermal electricity generation sectors. Gas production in Canada<br/>increased by 9.1 per cent to 26.5 bcf at a time of very strong North<br/>American gas prices. Oil production in both New Zealand and Canada<br/>fell, due to expected reservoir decline and preferential investment<br/>in gas developments in response to last year's low oil prices. The<br/>Maharaja Lela field in Brunei reached full contract production<br/>quantities, making an important contribution of 1.4 million barrels<br/>of oil equivalent over the period.<br/><br/>Net earnings of Fletcher Challenge Forests (FCF) were $4 million<br/>(excluding unusual and non-recurring items) compared with $6 million<br/>for the previous six months and $3 million for the comparative period<br/>in 1998. The comparative figures have been adjusted to exclude the<br/>results of the Chilean operations, which were sold last year, and<br/>which contributed $3 million to earnings in the June 1999 period.<br/><br/>Trading conditions were mixed, with strong sales of manufactured<br/>products in New Zealand and the United States, and a partial recovery<br/>in log demand from South East Asia; however export log prices picked<br/>up more slowly than volume.<br/><br/>Fletcher Challenge Paper (FCP) recorded net earnings (excluding<br/>unusual items) of $18 million, compared with a loss of $11 million in<br/>the June half-year and earnings of $18 million in the previous<br/>December half. Shipments for Paper operations were 1,010,000 tonnes<br/>(excluding shipments from the Malaysian mill), and were virtually<br/>unchanged from those for the six months ended December 1998.<br/><br/>Shipments of pulp and containerboard were 515,000 tonnes, an<br/>improvement of 52,000 tonnes over the comparable period. Production<br/>of paper, excluding Malaysia, was 1,112,000 tonnes (48.8gsm basis),<br/>almost identical to the same period in 1998. Production of pulp and<br/>containerboard was 516,000 tonnes, also comparable to 1998 levels.<br/><br/>GROUP RESTRUCTURING<br/>In December 1999, the Board of Directors of Fletcher Challenge<br/>Limited resolved to propose to shareholders the dismantling of the<br/>Group's targeted share structure. While the Board is determined to<br/>deliver optimal separation solutions quickly, it will not be<br/>artificially limited in this process by a timetable. Instead, timing<br/>will be determined by those transactions and options that maximise<br/>value for shareholders.<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">RWECO-FLC16020019221233</dc:identifier><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3YKD-BK80-001Y-34RC-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">157560</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1348"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP Company News</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2000 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4FCB-3410-015G-Y4VK-00000-00<published>2005-01-31T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 10</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Mail to: The Courier-Mail GPO Box 130 Brisbane 4001, fax 07 3666 6690, or email <email normalizedValue="mailto:cmletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au">cmletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p><p nitf:lede="true">Show mercy</p><p nitf:lede="true">for Pixie</p><p nitf:lede="true">CAN'T we show Pixie Skase some charity, regardless of her intemperate actions years ago, when she was probably heavily influenced by her late husband? Anyway, who wants to condemn an older lady to be separated from her family for whatever time she has left? -- Colin Williams, Fig Tree Pocket.</p><p nitf:lede="true">January 29</p><p nitf:lede="true"> * SORRY, Pixie Skase ("Pixie yearns to call Australia home again", C-M, Saturday). You dumped on Australia big-time, and it would be a contemptible disgrace for Minister Peter McGauran to give your appeal even a minute of his attention. I was a "pound stg. 10 pom" who did his nasho duty (1967-'69) when I could have skipped as you did. Your solicitor says your previous negative comments were like a hurtful throwaway line made to a former lover. Quite so. And as that relationship would have ended, so then did yours with Australia.-- David Hall, Southport.</p><p>January 29</p><p> * WE know Pixie Skase was stupid and unthinking in telling the Government where to put its citizenship, but their refusal to reinstate it smacks of pure vindictiveness. This could happen to any of us.-- R.H. Williams, Parrearra.</p><p>January 28</p><p> * SO, Pixie Skase wants to regain her Australian citizenship? She was quick to renounce it to reside in Majorca and live the high life derived from the ill-gotten gains of her late husband's deliberately orchestrated company deceptions. Now she wants to come crawling back to be with her family. What about the families Christopher Skase ruthlessly ruined, refusing to face, let alone make any reparations? Let her spend her declining years in luxurious exile pondering her willing participation in those events.-- Robyn Kirk, Albany Creek.</p><p>January 28</p><p>TV coverage makes us all experts</p><p>INTRODUCING video replays to provide more accuracy in tennis umpiring would appear to be common sense. However, in fairness to both parties, the whole rally (including the serve) would have to be scrutinised. The sport would lose its spontaneity, and booming music would have to be played to keep the crowd placated during these hiatuses.-- Graham Egan, Chermside.</p><p>January 29</p><p> * AS the Australian Open draws to a close, I ponder on how tennis has changed in recent years. It's become an audio spectacle rather than a visual one.</p><p>What began with Monica Seles grunting occasionally has escalated into a cacophony of unrelenting and quite ghastly proportions. I thought Wimbledon champion Maria Sharapova took the cake with her strident, shrill, ear-piercing shrieks. So passionate about her game, Sharapova seemed on the verge of an orgasm every time she touched the ball. I hate to think what a blind person would have made of it all.</p><p>I suspect Seles rues not patenting what she created, and tennis must rue not having immediately outlawed it.-- Crispin Walters, Chapel Hill.</p><p>January 29 * FROM time to time you hear people express the opinion that ABC cricket commentators are much better than their counterparts at certain television stations. I am not convinced ABC commentators could recognise, let alone describe, a game of cricket. For example, I tuned to today's ABC Radio coverage. The commentators mentioned a particular bowler had just taken two wickets in a row with the last two balls of his over and awaited his next over to see if he would procure a hat-trick. So what did the commentators do during the wait? Describe the over in between? Of course not. We were treated to the inarticulate whinging of one on how unhappy he was with the poor quality of the free lunch he had been provided as part of his job (which is, we should remember, the demanding task of watching cricket). The boys over at Kerry's clubhouse aren't perfect, but at least they talk about cricket (or cricket-related figurines).-- Shane Budden, Kenmore.</p><p>January 30</p><p>Keep horses on tracks</p><p>I READ Leon Misfeld's (outgoing director of the National Parks Association) reaction to horse riders using forest reserves (C-M, Saturday) -- that he was "determined to make sure reserves are not used for horse riding".</p><p>Currently, riders have access to some remaining fire trails in forest reserves that were previously state forest. That's native bush and plantation forests that are also available for beekeepers, some grazing licences, logging and a wide variety of recreation including horse riding. The horses are able to use the formed roads already maintained for forest fire protection. Horse riders don't want entry to pristine areas with delicate ecosystems.</p><p>I don't understand the mind-set of people who believe they have a right to close the door on all horse riding on state-owned land.</p><p>Closing horses out of forest tracks will put us back on the roads. You won't like that either, since the horse, as a vehicle, has right of way. How about giving some support to the horse riders using the formed fire breaks?-- Lee Flynn, Wamuran.</p><p>January 30</p><p>Behaviour tries patience</p><p>RE the claims a patient was assaulted by hospital security guards at PA Hospital; I spent considerable time at the PA having cancer treatment, and I have witnessed bad conduct and assaults carried out by patients on the hospital staff.</p><p>Notices warning patients have been posted everywhere. Four security guards is not unreasonable to evict an unruly patient and to minimise risk of damage to both the patient and to guards. Any patient who has two legs and two arms can strike out. How can a hospital deal with an unruly patient? Aren't hospital staff entitled to work in a safe place? If the hospital didn't have to employ so many security guards, perhaps more beds and facilities could be kept operational. -- Peter Sauerberg, Holland Park West.</p><p>January 29</p><p>Burbsville</p><p>perhaps?</p><p>VISITORS (former Brisbanites) to Brisbane before Christmas wondered at the use of the name "Bris Vegas" for Brisbane.</p><p>They were amused and disappointed, pointing out Brisbane certainly did not resemble Las Vegas in any way (C-M, Saturday).</p><p>Brisbane has only one little casino and poker machines. Brisbane does not have the regular top-line entertainment that Las Vegas (in the US) and other Australian capital cities have. So what is it with Bris Vegas? I'm proud to be a Queenslander (as were my visitors) born and bred. Why muck about with our historical place names? They are our heritage, not America's Vegas.</p><p>Brisbane is not the gambling capital of Australia. It has much more going for it than gambling. It has its own special subtropical climate and atmosphere and lifestyle. Isn't there some genius who can come up with a slogan that describes Brisbane's uniqueness? (And I don't mean River City either).  -- John Morris,</p><p>Aspley.</p><p>January 29</p><p>Letters and e-mail must be dated, carry the full address of the writer and a daytime telephone number for verification. Letters should be concise, topical, not more than 300 words and are submitted  on condition that Queensland Newspapers,as publisher of The Courier-Mail, may edit and has the right to, and license third parties to, reproduce in electronic form and communicate these letters.</p><p>Beazley no</p><p>consolation</p><p>YOUR editorial and columns by various journalists about the recycled Beazley fail to detail the reasons for his previous electoral "success". Such omissions closely mirror the denial factor inside the ALP which sees the re-emergence of a two-time election loser.</p><p>Much is made of the fact that the ALP amassed 51 per cent of the vote in 1998 without gaining a majority of seats. Beazley didn't gain those extra votes, John Howard sacrificed them. As with Bob Hawke, who in the 1980s refused to allow then treasurer Paul Keating to introduce a broad-based consumption tax, Howard knew significant tax reform such as a GST could only be done on the back of a landslide election win, such as in 1996.</p><p>As for 2001, the ALP and left-leaning commentators continue to blame the Tampa for its third consecutive federal poll defeat, while completely ignoring the crucial swing to the Coalition in a by-election a few months earlier.</p><p>Beazley's enduring personal ambition is not the answer. However a major overhaul of the party akin to Blair's "new" Labour in Britain might, at least, give our democracy the strong opposition party every Government needs.-- Richard Read, Indooroopilly.</p><p>January 29</p><p> * THE Labor Party is slow to learn. Newly elected Opposition Leader Kim Beazley has wasted no time in dumping predecessor Mark Latham's policies. He seems to forget one of the major criticisms of his party is that voters no longer know what Labor stands for. Beazley's actions will further reinforce this view. Maybe the Labor Party should bring back Gough Whitlam. This would be "generational change" of the first order. At least people knew what Whitlam stood for.-- Chris Macdade, Shailer Park.</p><p>January 30</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4DXY-T540-015G-Y1T4-00000-00<published>2004-12-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 34</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Mail to: The Courier-Mail GPO Box 130 Brisbane 4001, fax 07 3666 6690, or email <email normalizedValue="mailto:cmletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au">cmletters@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p><p nitf:lede="true">Public</p><p nitf:lede="true">service</p><p nitf:lede="true">IT never ceases to amaze me how many rorts and schemes The Courier-Mail manages to uncover.</p><p nitf:lede="true">I applaud you and your journalists. This time (C-M, Dec 3), it is Veterans Affairs De-Anne Kelly allowing her husband to have a parliamentary, taxpayer-funded e-mail account. The public knows little enough of what goes on, so keep up the good work.-- Josephine Watson, Burpengary.</p><p>December 3</p><p> Dressed</p><p>for court</p><p>THURSDAY'S court appearance by homeless Ziggy was not, I hope, an acceptance of lowered standards for witnesses in the new Magistrates Court (C-M, Dec 3). The wearing of gloves by the attending police officers showed that caution was necessary to prevent a possible health risk. Some sympathy for his way of living -- his choice -- is unavoidable but surely the court's prestige suffers by allowing him to carry his entire belongings encased in used plastic bags into a public arena. I suppose they must have passed the metal detectors.-- B. Lawrence, Bardon.</p><p>December 3</p><p> Shared</p><p>culpability?</p><p>I REFER to the controversy over compensation by James Hardie for sufferers of mesothelioma.</p><p>Surely work-contracted ailment comes under state workers' compensation schemes? Why aren't the various governments also being held liable? They knew as far back as the early 1960s that asbestos dust caused this medical condition. Why did they not stop its production at that time? They failed to do so and, surely, are equally as culpable as James Hardie.</p><p> -- Anthony H. Jakeman, Coondoo.</p><p>December 3</p><p>Gathered under Southern Cross</p><p>AS A native-born Australian, I am disgusted that the democratically elected Prime Minister of our country will have nothing to do with the 150th anniversary celebrations of the Eureka rebellion.</p><p>John Howard's views are probably influenced by the idea that the Eureka flag, featuring the Southern Cross, has been tainted by its use by left-wing unions. This has no validity.</p><p>In world terms, the 1854 rebellion may have been an insignificant event in the Antipodes, but in terms of its effect on the growth of democracy in an infant country, it was a hugely important event that meant someone with Howard's views could become the nation's leader.</p><p> I am not a republican but I believe that we should exchange the Queen's Birthday holiday to mark Eureka Day instead.-- Bob Whiteman, The Gap.</p><p>December 3</p><p> *  THOSE who believe that the Eureka stockade was the birth of democracy in Australia have little understanding of the colonies and colonial power in the 1800s.</p><p>Russia, China, Vietnam, Cuba and North Korea have re-written their nations' histories. So it seems have some socialist historians in Australia.</p><p>Eureka was nothing more than a demonstration and a stand against taxation of the time.-- Robert Buick, Mountain Creek.</p><p>December 3</p><p> *  I CAN'T believe that the organisers of Sunday's march in Ballarat commemorating the Eureka stockade have asked Terry Hicks to lead it. His son, David, does not represent the Eureka spirit. He is charged with attempted murder, conspiracy to commit war crimes and aiding the enemy. Some hero.-- David Innes, Edge Hill.</p><p>December 2</p><p>Jet boat plan almost passed us by</p><p>EACH quarter, Brisbane City Council sends us a chatty newsletter to soften the blow of the accompanying rates notice.</p><p>I find fascinating titbits about tai chi classes in the park and macrame classes, but nothing has ever been mentioned about jet-boat thrill rides on the river.</p><p>I knew nothing of this until a neighbour drew my attention to Chris Griffith's article (C-M, Nov 30). It seems to have been an extraordinarily well-kept secret. Did Lord Mayor Campbell Newman know about this, or was he too busy beavering or tunnelling around other parts of the river bank? Did Deputy Mayor David Hinchliffe, who recently was engaged on the important topic of wearing shorts to work, overlook mentioning the matter to the Lord Mayor.</p><p>What about Cr Judy Magub, our representative at St Lucia? Has she been imprisoned in the dungeons of the City Hall? It is hard to understand why she would otherwise be silent on the subject. It was comforting to read that at least Cr Graham Quirk, Transport and Major Projects Committee chairman, had heard about the scheme. It was not so comforting to find that he had "no principled objection to the jet boats".</p><p>We are told that Preston Richardson, the owner of Jet Boats Brisbane, has a lot of confidence in the proposal and has begun building an expensive jet boat which he knows will burn and pirouette its way into our hearts and minds.</p><p>It puzzles me that he has done so in advance of any regulation or authority.</p><p>The article has caused a lot of concern among my neighbours. They are concerned primarily about safety -- crashes with canoeists and CityCats. Some have expressed fears about the worsening of erosion and the noise factor. They are not too keen on the promised screeching and screams as the machine performs its tricks along quiet reaches of the river.</p><p>For my part, I am angry that years of good planning and remarkable improvement to the river bank could be despoiled.-- Ian Buchanan, St Lucia.</p><p>December 3</p><p>Riding roughshod over equestrians</p><p>IT IS disgraceful the way in which the State Government is forcing horse riders out of state forests where they have ridden for decades.</p><p>Horse riders are a non-mainstream group and are treated like other non-mainstream groups by the Government -- that is, poorly. The forests that are to be re-named national parks are, in the main, bits of hard, rubbishy ground that already have been logged and have had cattle leases on them for years. Riders ride on hard forest fire trails and to suggest that they cause the spread of weeds is ignorant.</p><p> Banishing horses from forests areas and yet continuing to allow trail bikes and four-wheel-drives makes a nonsense of claims that this move is about conserving sensitive environmental areas.</p><p>The main purpose should be to keep some green forests around the southeast. This could be achieved by claiming them as conservation parks or at least allowing some conservation trails on existing tracks in these areas so riders could use them. That would be inclusive government, recognising diversity of interests and activity.-- Anne Winning, Coolum.</p><p> December 3</p><p>Defence</p><p>cop-out</p><p>THE academics who were miffed by Prime Minister John Howard's refusal to sign the ASEAN non-aggression treaty forget that, between the two world wars, more countries signed more pacts and peace treaties than you could poke a .303 at and only a fool called Neville Chamberlain believed they stopped anyone pulling the trigger.</p><p>Our cousins over "The Pond", who are down to six nearly 40-year-old fighting aircraft that they can't agree how to rearm, and whose only means of invading anyone, a new amphibious ship, was such a lemon it was scrapped after a few months, are probably living in mortal fear of being invaded by the Pitcairners and would doubtless sign anything, in hope, rather than pull their weight in regional defence matters.-- Doug Macdonald, Eatons Hill.</p><p>December 2</p><p>Invite to</p><p>Golden City</p><p>AS a big fan of Strictly Dancing on ABC TV, I was mortified to hear host Paul McDermott slander the beautiful city of Gympie -- not once, but three times -- on national TV.</p><p>He was speaking either from ignorance or blind prejudice. I challenge him to visit this lovely, sunny city nestled in the "Tuscany of Australia", with its rolling green hills and wooded slopes. I invite him to drink an espresso at a little "terrasse de cafe" under the shady trees in the winding main street; shop in its quaint little boutiques; chat with the kind and friendly people; visit the wonderful heritage buildings steeped in Australia's history; ride the little steam train through the scenic Mary Valley.</p><p>If McDermott does these things and still scorns Gympie, then we will know that he would detest paradise. -- C. Clifford, Chatsworth.</p><p> November 26</p><p>Letters and e-mail must be dated, carry the full address of the writer and a daytime telephone number for verification. Letters should be concise, topical, not more than 300 words and are submitted  on condition that Queensland Newspapers,as publisher of The Courier-Mail, may edit and has the right to, and license third parties to, reproduce in electronic form and communicate these letters.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3W06-XY60-001Y-303B-00000-00<published>1999-03-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Part 2 of 7</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CUE - Half Yearly Report</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Sydney</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p><br/>HOMEX - Melbourne<br/>-------------------------<br/>Half Yearly Report<br/>3. EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES<br/>PPL 189 - Papuan Basin, PNG (14.141% Interest)<br/>During the half year, additional processing was undertaken on the 13<br/>kilometre Pit Pit seismic line over the Barikewa gas field. The line<br/>ties the Barikewa-1 and 2 wells.<br/><br/>A reassessment of other structural leads in the licence was completed<br/>and preparations were begun for a geological survey over the<br/>north-western part of Barikewa and the Kopi lead in southern most PPL<br/>189.<br/><br/>PPL 190 - Papuan Basin, PNG (10.535% Interest)<br/>During the half year, the landowner dispute over ownership of the<br/>Healy-1 drilling site remained unresolved. The Minister, at the<br/>request of the Joint Venture, suspended the licence conditions for a<br/>minimum of twelve months.</p><section sectionType="slug"><bodyText><p>CUE</p></bodyText></section><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Australian Associated Press</p></bodyText></section><p><br/>Consequently, the Parker Rig 125, which was to drill Healy-1 was<br/>demobilised and an alternative rig will be used, possibly around mid<br/>year 1999.<br/><br/>PPL 193 - Papuan Basin, PNG (7.5% Interest)<br/>In October 1998, Cue announced that it would earn a 7.5% interest in<br/>PPL 193 Papua New Guinea and would participate in the drilling of the<br/>Kimu-1 and Koko-1 wells.<br/><br/>Subject to necessary PNG Government approvals, Cue is obtaining a<br/>3.75% interest from Oil Search Limited and a 3.75% interest from Gedd<br/>Inc by paying 15% of the costs of drilling the Kimu-1 and Koko-1<br/>wells up to a total Cue share of US$ 1.651 million. Any drilling costs<br/>above a gross cost of US$ 11,006,667 for the two wells will be paid by<br/>Cue at its earned equity level of 7.5%.<br/><br/>The Kimu-1 well spudded on 21st November 1998. Subsequent to the end<br/>of this half year Kimu-1 encountered a 32 metre gas column in the<br/>Alene sandstone. Drill Stem Test (DST) 1 was conducted over the<br/>interval 1620-1642 metres in the Alene sandstone using open hole<br/>straddle packers. The well flowed gas at a rate of 7.79mmscfg/d<br/>through a 0.5 inch choke with a well head flowing pressure of<br/>1205psia. The well flowed with a draw-down of only 2.7 psi showing a<br/>highly productive sand with an interpreted permeability of<br/>approximately 8,000md. There was no pressure depletion as a result of<br/>the test with the initial pressure agreeing with the final shut-in<br/>pressure (2316.4psia). Samples taken during the course of the test<br/>will be analysed for compositional information.<br/><br/>The results of the DST indicated that the Alene sandstone is a highly<br/>prolific gas producer at the Kimu location. Based on the results of<br/>the DST the Alene sandstone has the potential to produce at rates<br/>well above 50 mmscfg/d from an optimised well bore. Due to the small<br/>hole diameter in the Kimu well over the gas zone, which limits the<br/>ability to effectively produce gas, the well was plugged and<br/>abandoned.<br/><br/>A series of pressure date points (SFT's) and sidewall cores were<br/>collected over the open hole interval. The pressure data indicated<br/>that the Kimu-1 well had penetrated a 32 metre gas saturated Alene<br/>interval with an interpreted gas/water contact coincident with the<br/>shale break at the base of the Alene sand at 1649 mKB. Updip<br/>potential remains at the Kimu location. Samples taken from the deeper<br/>intervals confirmed that the Toro, Hedinia and Iagifu sandstones were<br/>water saturated, however, one sample from the top of the Hedinia<br/>Sandstone at 1873.5 metres recovered formation water with an oil<br/>film.<br/><br/>The wireline logging and DST program in the Kimu well has confirmed<br/>the well as a new gas field discovery in the Alene sandstone.<br/><br/>Kimu-1 tested a prospect in the northern Omati Trough within the<br/>foreland basin of Papua New Guinea. The gas saturated Alene sandstone<br/>and the fluorescence noted in the Hedinia and Iagifu reservoirs while<br/>drilling and during sampling after the well reached total depth has<br/>confirmed the Omati Trough area as an active petroleum system. Kimu-1<br/>is the first of a two well program in PPL193, Koko-1 will be drilled<br/>immediately following Kimu-1 and will test a large old structure on<br/>the leading edge of the Komewu Fault that bounds the southern margin<br/>of the Omati Trough. Koko-1 is located substantially updip and 28<br/>kilometres west of Kimu-1.<br/><br/>Subsequent to the end of the half year, Koko-1 was drilled to a total<br/>depth of 1,363 metres. Natural gas was recovered by wireline sampling<br/>from the Upper Hedinia Sandstone and natural gas and 200 cc of heavy<br/>oil were recovered from the Lower Imburu Sandstone. The well has been<br/>plugged and abandoned as a sub-commercial oil and gas discovery.<br/><br/>The oil and gas accumulations defined in Koko-1 and the Kimu-1 gas<br/>discovery, demonstrate that an active and significant hydrocarbon<br/>charge is present in the Foreland of Papua New Guinea, which further<br/>upgrades the prospectivity of the licence and the eastern Foreland<br/>area as a whole. Additional studies will be required to fully<br/>understand the results of the Kimu-1 well and Koko-1 drilling program<br/>and the impact on hydrocarbon potential in this lightly explored<br/>area.<br/><br/>PPL 194 - Papuan Basin, PNG (100% Interest)<br/>In November 1998, the Minister granted Toro Oil Pty Ltd, a wholly<br/>owned subsidiary of Cue Energy Resources No Liability, Petroleum<br/>Prospecting Licence PPL 194 in the Papua New Guinea highlands.<br/><br/>PPL 194 covers 6,200 square kilometres and is situated to the north<br/>east of the Paua and Moran oil fields in the central fold belt.<br/><br/>Tanjung Jabung PSC - South Sumatra Basin, Indonesia (76% Interest)<br/>The Tanjung Jabung Production Sharing Contract is nearing the end of<br/>Contract year 2 (15 May 1999). The contract requires the expenditure<br/>of US$ 15.2 million on seismic and drilling in the initial three year<br/>period.<br/><br/>Despite being content with its 42.2885% holding, during the half<br/>year, Cue involuntarily increased its not effective interest in the<br/>PSC from 42.2885% to 76% by virtue of a default by Wirabuana<br/>Petrolindo Ltd.<br/><br/>At the end of the half year, the planned initial seismic survey had<br/>not been undertaken due to access being denied by the Department of<br/>Forestry and Plantation, to acquire seismic over the two most<br/>promising prospects which lie within the Berbak National Park. The<br/>Park occupies the most prospective portion of the contract area. The<br/>existence of the National Park was not disclosed at the time the<br/>Production Sharing Contract area was offered and was not known at the<br/>time of the award to the Joint Venture.<br/><br/>The Berbak National Park is the first wet land area in Indonesia<br/>designated as a Wildlife Reserve and is bound by the Convention on<br/>Wetlands and on the Protection of Weiland Birds and other Migrating<br/>Birds.<br/><br/>The National Park is home to some three hundred species of permanent<br/>and migrating birds as well as river mouth crocodiles, tapirs,<br/>rhinoceros and several species of monkeys. Within the National Park<br/>an integrated swamp development project is being funded by the World<br/>Bank and a forest fire control project has attracted international<br/>funding.<br/><br/>The custodian of the National Park, the Department of Forestry and<br/>Plantation, has stated categorically that it will not grant a permit<br/>for any exploration (or exploitation activities within the National<br/>Park areas (see copy of translated letter attached).<br/><br/>Cue is examining various options for its interest in the Production<br/>Sharing Contract, including the possibility of withdrawing from the<br/>Tanjung Jabung Joint Venture, in order to concentrate the Company's<br/>energy and resources on other areas that have more potential to<br/>increase shareholder value.<br/><br/>Sampang PSC-Madura Strait, East Java, Indonesia (15% Interest)<br/>During the half year, a 564km in-fill grid of new seismic data was<br/>acquired in the contract area. Processing of the new 1998 seismic<br/>data and reprocessing of the existing seismic data continued during<br/>the half year.<br/><br/>A biostratigraphic review of wells in the Sampang PSC area was<br/>completed and a geological field survey was conducted on Madura<br/>Island and onshore East Java. The survey was designed to examine<br/>selected rock outcrops and to sample oil and gas seeps to gather<br/>information that could impact on the prospectivity of the offshore<br/>Sampang block.<br/><br/>EP 363 Carnarvon Basin - Western Australia (17.65% Interest)<br/>In July 1998, Apache Energy exercised an option to acquire an<br/>additional 25% interest in the permit. Apache will acquire its<br/>additional equity by paying 37% of the costs for the acquisition and<br/>processing of 3D marine seismic to a cap of AUD2 million. Apache also<br/>assumed operatorship of the permit as of 1st September 1998. As a<br/>result of the exercise of the option Cue's interest reduced from 25%<br/>to 17.65%.<br/><br/>The Joint venture is considering the acquisition of non proprietary<br/>3D seismic data over a significant portion of the permit.<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">RWECO-CUE100399271431</dc:identifier><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3W06-XY60-001Y-303B-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">157560</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1411"/><timeReceived>14:31</timeReceived><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP Company News</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty.
