urn:contentItem:49K3-KDC0-01S8-81DS-00000-00<published>1987-07-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MENTAL AS ANYTHING</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mouth To Mouth (CBS)</p><p nitf:lede="true">THIS album is as good a picture as anything of a band's struggling to stretch itself. Mental As Anything is still master of the quirky, whimsical lyric but appears to be developing a fuller sense of maturity in its music.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Listen to Don't Tell Me Now . It sets the mood for the album with a full, textured brass section and Martin Plaza's voice catches just the right measure of tension.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Plaza's songwriting abilities shine through on the record. Put Me Back is enough to showcase his own vocal ability and remains a concise, pleasing song.</p><p>Let's Go To Paradise is the complete pop song, and demonstrates an extension of Greedy Smith's benevolent style of lyrics. With Greedy it always seems to be "it's-you-and-me-against-them, kid". One finds similar advocacy on He's Just No Good For You.</p><p> Peter O'Doherty's The Mad King is the album's deepest song musically but lyrically it just does not seem to fit, lacking the structures and knife-like twists of Smith and Plaza's better work.</p><p> That aside, this work is a complete step forward.</p><p>Andrew Male</p><p>NEIL YOUNG</p><p>& CRAZY HORSE</p><p>Life (WEA)</p><p> SOME years before the Springsteen phenomenon, Neil Young was described as America's greatest living rock legend. The label was a tribute to Young's passion and integrity, his constant re-evaluation of his values and musical direction. He has weaved in and out of power rock, pop rock and country rock for 20 years: Life is a return, albeit with some annoying '80s manifestations, to those uncompromising early days of Crazy Horse.</p><p> Young's classic strangled, rough-hewn guitar sound gives Life</p><p>a sense of raw energy missing from some of his later work, without rejecting the soul-searching vulnerability which has been the very foundation of his following. But there is a disturbing barrier between artist and listener caused, undoubtedly, by an overkill of computer drum programming and special effects.</p><p> Apart from a bit of red-necked nastiness called Mideast Vacation , which is immediately remedied by the more thoughtful anthem Long Walk Home, the album is the usual Young blend of substantial rockers and painful memories. Prisoners Of Rock'n'Roll and Cryin' Eyes fill the former category, while When Your Lonely Heart Breaks and We Never Danced are best saved for late at night when the remorse is running high and the bottle is low. Inca Queen is a rolling narrative in the best Cowgirls In The Sand sense, perhaps the most complete track of the album.</p><p> However, the final word must go to the credited army of programmers and engineers, drum tech and guitar tech who put the crash-bash and boring beat between singer and song. It seems a strange mismatch to someone who still rates After The Goldrush one of the great albums of the rock era.</p><p>Chris Bowe</p><p>UB40</p><p>CCCP Live in Moscow (Virgin)</p><p> UB40 didn't sound very comfortable in Moscow, considering its sympathetic political leanings and a musically starved audience. CCCP seems rushed and wooden: the band managed to get 13 tracks of its busy urban reggae on the album, so it must have been a wham-bam-thank-you-mam concert.</p><p> The overall impression is not helped by a very flat recording, even if it was remixed back in England. In fact, successive tracks Keep On Moving, Watch Dogs and Don't Blame Me are so uniform they almost sound the same.</p><p> Still, all the favorites are there, with Please Don't Make Me Cry, I Got You Babe (even without Chrissie Hynde) and Sing Our Own Song generating respectful enthusiasm. But only in Rat In My Kitchen did the band seem to relax and generate the level of energy that would have been demanded at home.</p><p> Not one for the archives.</p><p>Chris Bowe</p><p>VARIOUS</p><p> PAT Metheny's latest, Still Life Talking (WEA), and the combined talents of George Benson and Earl Klugh on Collaboration (Warner Brothers) share common virtues and lesser qualities. Both are smooth, laid-back affairs with superficial appeal but lacking substance or a raison d'aitre. Metheny's more ethereal light jazz scores more points, especially for the breezy Latin rhythms of It's Just talk and Third Wind. George Benson's worst mistake was to discover he could sing: since then his guitar playing has lacked bite. And on Collaboration, the acoustic work of Klugh is too subtle to rise above the Benson formula. Expect to hear this on high-rise office musak before long. English Renaissance (PolyGram) makes for pleasant dinner music from traditional acoustic guitarist John Themis. This classical guitar is not challenging enough for the purist but soothes the undemanding ear of an irritable plebeian at the end of the day.</p><p> Sipho Mabuse (Virgin), by the artist of the same name, is a rather obvious attempt to jump on the African music bandwagon. The music is already santitised and as remote to Africa as modern reggae is to the Carribean, with tracks as trite as Let's Get It On and Jive Soweto.</p><p>Japanese synthesiser devotee Kitaro is having another crack at the world market with An Introduction (Polydor), which seems to be a selection from albums that date back to 1980. Kitaro uses his toy in the classical sense, producing a haunting but mournful amalgam of styles Western and Japanese. Nice sounds but a little funereal in large doses.</p><p>Chris Bowe</p><p>DEAD KENNEDYS</p><p>Plastic Surgery Disasters (Virgin)</p><p> HEAVEN help us all if the Dead Kennedys ever cross into the mainstream of music.</p><p> If the Kennedys become just another pop group one shudders to think of what will occupy the "weird" side of rock.</p><p> Plastic Surgery Disasters is a bona-fide, blue chip excursion into some exceptionally good music.</p><p> The music thrashes and bites like a live shark in a fishing net.</p><p> Government Flu sounds like a good Midnight Oil song. The singer throws the words to some angry guitars which spit and snap in a machinegun chord progression.</p><p> Imagine something like A Whiter Shade of Pale played at 78 rpm and you'd be close to the Dead Kennedys' modus operandi.</p><p> Splinters of the Violent Femmes fly past the listener in Terminal Preppie , although it steers away from that band's paranoid and beautiful lyrics in favor of a guitar assault.</p><p> The relatively gentle start of Forest Fire sounds almost like it would make an AOR playlist.</p><p> Feel horror then relax, it kicks into gear in the second verse and goes berserk like we all know it should.</p><p> Keep this album away from the children.</p><p>Andrew Male</p><p>HEART</p><p>Bad Animals (Capitol)</p><p> THE Canadian glamor girls Ann and Nancy Wilson apparently have only to look sexy on stage and they manage another million-seller. Their popularity is such that a few flashes of thigh and some sultry sighs will ensure further success for Bad Animals - stadium rock with a touch of glamor. It's the usual formula - none of the exciting rock which marked their debut album Dreamboat Annie - some chugging rockers and a couple of powerful ballads like the current hit Alone fleshed out with lots of swirling synthesisers and big choral arrangements.</p><p> Who Will You Turn To, There's The Girl, and You Ain't So Tough</p><p>generate some excitement, while Wait For An Answer matches the intensity of Alone.</p><p> The vocal power of Ann and Nancy shows to best effect on the slower numbers where their voices soar above the lavish backing.</p><p> But the lady lead guitarist bit does seem slightly overdone on such tracks as Bad Animals where Nancy Wilson sends her guitar into an orgasmic frenzy - perhaps in an attempt to prove she can tackle Jimmy Page head-on.</p><p> So despite all the posturing, Heart's latest attempt is just more of the same - except in this case there is one important ingredient missing - a bit of heart.</p><p>Greg Kelton</p><p>DAVID KNOPFLER</p><p>Cut The Wire (Interfusion)</p><p> PITY poor David Knopfler. Ever since he left Dire Straits at the time of Making Movies as a result of a stoush with brother Mark, he's had to live very much in the shadow of the man who has put Straits at the top of the charts.</p><p> Cut The Wire is DK's third solo album since the split. And at last it can be said that he is out of the shadows and in the spotlight because of his own music. This is a good album</p><p>- and despite the obvious similarities to the music of his big brother (who, after all, IS Dire Straits) - it withstands any comparisons.</p><p> While the better tracks such as Freakshow and The Hurricane</p><p>do sound like out-takes from a Straits recording session, they are very strong songs in their own right and I'm sure Mark Knopfler would like to have written a song like When We Kiss , an obvious candidate for the singles charts.</p><p> Knopfler has not tried anything fancy with Cut The Wire and that is one of its strengths. He has not tried to move too far from the music he liked to play when he was in Dire Straits.</p><p> Both musically, and lyrically, David Knopfler has come of age. It remains to be seen whether he can reach the same giddy heights of success as Knopfler Mark I. But on this showing he at least deserves a chance.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>photo: mental as anything; Mental As Anything: developing a fuller sense of maturityin its music.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XYG-K6C1-JC0X-K1B7-00000-00<published>2020-01-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 11 AAP - The death toll from Victoria's bushfire crisis has risen to four after a firefighter died battling a blaze in the state's alpine region.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter from Parks Victoria was killed while battling a blaze in the Omeo area on Saturday, Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed.<br/>   "Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said in a statement.<br/>   ?The safety and wellbeing of our people is our highest priority.?<br/>   The firefighter's death will be investigated by Victoria Police, who will prepare a report for the coroner.<br/>   It comes after another Forest Fires Management worker Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed in the fires at East Gippsland on New Year's Day.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYG-K6C1-JC0X-K1B7-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="166"/><timeReceived>10:36 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XYK-J8H1-JC0X-K1PF-00000-00<published>2020-01-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 11 AAP - The death toll from Victoria's bushfire crisis has risen to four after a firefighter died battling a blaze in the state's alpine region.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter from Parks Victoria was killed while battling a blaze in the Omeo area on Saturday, Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed.<br/>   "Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said in a statement.<br/>   ?The safety and wellbeing of our people is our highest priority.?<br/>   The firefighter's death will be investigated by Victoria Police, who will prepare a report for the coroner.<br/>   It comes after another Forest Fires Management worker Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed in the fires at East Gippsland on New Year's Day.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYK-J8H1-JC0X-K1PF-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-12</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="166"/><timeReceived>10:36 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5Y0N-SW31-DYG0-907Y-00000-00<published>2020-01-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Marnie Banger<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 17 AAP - Fireworks on Australia Day won't be going ahead in the heart of Melbourne, because staff at a public agency are flat out dealing with the bushfire crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Victorian government has cancelled the fireworks display it sponsors at Docklands because it is supported by staff at Parks Victoria who are busy with deadly bushfires in East Gippsland and the northeast.<br/>   Parks Victoria supports the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, as part of Forest Fire Management Victoria, to prepare for, fight and recover from such blazes.<br/>   "While we understand that this decision may disappoint some families, the focus right now of Parks Victoria is, and has to be, on working with our other emergency services in the firefighting effort and the recovery of communities and wildlife," a government spokeswoman said on Friday.<br/>   Other Australia Day events and fireworks displays organised by local councils will continue as planned.<br/>   The impact of the fires on communities and the efforts of emergency service workers will be acknowledged during formal proceedings at some events.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5Y0N-SW31-DYG0-907Y-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="188"/><timeReceived>5:43 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. Fireworks on Australia Day won't be going ahead in the heart of Melbourne, because staff at a public agency are flat out dealing with the bushfire crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Victorian government has cancelled the fireworks display it sponsors at Docklands because it is supported by staff at Parks Victoria who are busy with deadly bushfires in East Gippsland and the northeast.<br/>   Parks Victoria supports the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, as part of Forest Fire Management Victoria, to prepare for, fight and recover from such blazes.<br/>   "While we understand that this decision may disappoint some families, the focus right now of Parks Victoria is, and has to be, on working with our other emergency services in the firefighting effort and the recovery of communities and wildlife," a government spokeswoman said on Friday.<br/>   Other Australia Day events and fireworks displays organised by local councils will continue as planned.<br/>   The impact of the fires on communities and the efforts of emergency service workers will be acknowledged during formal proceedings at some events.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5Y0W-CCR1-JC0X-K02D-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-18</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="188"/><timeReceived>5:43 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XXS-2631-DYG0-945D-00000-00<published>2020-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - A third person is confirmed to have died in Victoria's bushfires.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>    Forest Fires Management worker Matt Kavanagh, 43, died when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville confirmed on Friday his death was related to the bushfires, following a police investigation.<br/>   "Matt was a dedicated and respected member of Forest Fire Management Victoria for around 10 years and was on duty as a part of our fire response on the day," she told reporters.<br/>   "He's being remembered for his friendly and welcoming nature, his passion for the environment and nature and his love of fly fishing."<br/>   "It's a devastating loss for everybody in the sector but for those people who knew Matt it's going to take a long time, I can't imagine what they are going through,"Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said.<br/>   A colleague was taken to hospital following the accident and has since been released.<br/>   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed while battling bushfires this season.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XXS-2631-DYG0-945D-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-08</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="187"/><timeReceived>4:05 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. Victoria, Australia, April 11 -- Defence Materiel Organisation - Land Systems Division has a requirement for "Supply of Fire Fighting Equipment."

Bidding Type: International Competitive Bidding

The ATM Id. is PBMQ-0049/2011.

According to the description: "Request for Tender for Supply of Fire Fighting Equipment

NSN 4210-66-147-6892 Knapsack Sprayer - Qty 400 Procurement Description: Knapsack Sprayer, Back Pack Style, Plastic, Hand Pump Operated, with Shoulder Harness, Quick Release Strap back Tank Collapsible, Water Only Part No. AJ464 NSN 4210-66-017-9370 Beater Forest Fire - Qty 200 Procurement Description: Canvas Part No: 113199NSN 4210-66-154-5548 Nozzle Fire Extinguisher - Qty 10 Procurement Description: Brass, 60mm Lg, BSP Female inlet, c/w chain and hook Part No. 109753NSN 4210-66-139-3738 Blanket Fire - Qty 20 Procurement Description: 2.45m x 1.6m, used for heat and smoke shielding and first aid application Part No. HYDROGEL 2.45M X 1.6M."

Project Location: Australia

The expression of interest should be received by April 11 till 12 p.m. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:5XK5-MYH1-DYG0-93DG-00000-00<published>2019-11-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>updates with pic<br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 24 AAP - Hikers in Victoria's Mount Bogong High Plains have been advised to leave immediately, following the closure of a number of walking tracks in the area.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   An uncontrolled bushfire in the state's alpine region is travelling uphill towards the peak of Mt Bogong.<br/>   The mountain walking tracks have been closed to ensure the safety of people in the area.<br/>    The fires continue to burn after being ignited by lightning on Thursday, Forest Fire Management Victoria reported on Sunday.<br/>   The fires have grown in size since then, the largest being an estimated 300 hectares.<br/>     ?The remote locations of these fires are proving to be challenging for our crews and we fully expect them to burn for a number of weeks as firefighters work hard to contain them,"Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.<br/>    ?While no communities are currently under threat, we need residents to remain informed if conditions change.?<br/>   A Watch and Act alert has also been issued for a bushfire burning in the Gippsland region and aTotal Fire Ban has been announced for Monday for the Northern Country and Mallee.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XK5-MYH1-DYG0-93DG-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="194"/><timeReceived>7:20 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XK5-MYH1-DYG0-93CW-00000-00<published>2019-11-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 24 AAP - Hikers in Victoria's Mount Bogong High Plains have been advised to leave immediately, following the closure of a number of walking tracks in the area.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   An uncontrolled bushfire in the state's alpine region is travelling uphill towards the peak of Mt Bogong.<br/>   The mountain walking tracks have been closed to ensure the safety of people in the area.<br/>    The fires continue to burn after being ignited by lightning on Thursday, Forest Fire Management Victoria reported on Sunday.<br/>   The fires have grown in size since then, the largest being an estimated 300 hectares.<br/>     ?The remote locations of these fires are proving to be challenging for our crews and we fully expect them to burn for a number of weeks as firefighters work hard to contain them,"Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.<br/>    ?While no communities are currently under threat, we need residents to remain informed if conditions change.?<br/>   A Watch and Act alert has also been issued for a bushfire burning in the Gippsland region and aTotal Fire Ban has been announced for Monday for the Northern Country and Mallee.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XK5-MYH1-DYG0-93CW-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="192"/><timeReceived>6:28 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:402D-F8H0-0048-T4DG-00000-00<published>2000-04-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>SA: Children may have sparked forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p><br/>Bushfires SA<br/><br/>ADELAIDE, April 18 AAP - Children were thought responsible for a<br/>forest fire which destroyed about six hectares of pine plantation<br/>in South Australia's south-east yesterday afternoon.</p><p>           The Country Fire Service said investigations were continuing but<br/>it was believed children might have started the blaze just north of<br/>Naracoorte.<br/>            It took local crews about 15 minutes to bring it under control.<br/>            The damage bill could go as high as $10,000 with many of the<br/>young pines not expected to recover.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2000</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:402D-F8H0-0048-T4DG-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="95"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2000 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5WT8-4BY1-F0JP-W12V-00000-00<published>2019-08-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 9</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIGHT FIRE Three hundred new firefighters are needed for the upcoming fire season this summer. Men and women can apply to join Forest Fire Management Victoria as a seasonal project firefighter. Applications close on Sunday, August 25.</p><p>jobs.careers.vic.gov.au/pff</p><p>NO OFFENCE New laws will ban vehicles with offensive images or slogans from travelling on Victorian roads. Under the legislation, to be presented at parliament later this year, any registered vehicle that displays sexist, obscene or offensive slogans can be reviewed against the Australian Association of National Advertisers Code of Ethics.</p><p>BRAIN WAVES Take part in The Aha! Challenge this month and help Melbourne University researchers better understand how the human brain works. The challenge is a set of online brain teasers that take about 15 minutes to complete, designed to explore the range and types of insight experienced by individuals.</p><p>ahachallenge.net.au</p><p>ON A BOAT The State Government has abolished parking and launching fees at public boat ramps. It is expected all public boat ramps across Victoria will be free to use by spring.transport.vic.gov.au</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5WT8-4BY1-F0JP-W1N7-00000-00<published>2019-08-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:17Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 5</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIGHT FIRE Three hundred new firefighters are needed for the upcoming fire season this summer. Men and women can apply to join Forest Fire Management Victoria as a seasonal project firefighter. Applications close Sunday August 25.</p><p>jobs.careers.vic.gov.au/pff</p><p>NO OFFENCE New laws will ban vehicles with offensive images or slogans from travelling on Victorian roads. Under the legislation, to be presented at parliament later this year, any registered vehicle that displays sexist, obscene or offensive slogans can be reviewed against the Australian Association of National Advertisers Code of Ethics.</p><p>BRAIN WAVES Take part in The Aha! Challenge this month and help Melbourne University researchers better understand how the human brain works. The challenge is a set of online brain teasers that take about 15 minutes to complete, designed to explore the range and types of insight experienced by individuals.</p><p>ahachallenge.net.au</p><p>ON A BOAT The State Government has abolished parking and launching fees at public boat ramps. It is expected all public boat ramps across Victoria will be free to use by spring.transport.vic.gov.au</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>NADINE MORTON</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIREFIGHTERS were on scene at a forest fire west of Bathurst near The Rocks on Tuesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Crews received a call out to the fire at 5.15pm on Monday.</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) spokesperson Ben Shepherd said the 21-hectare blaze was burning through steep terrain.</p><p>"There are three trucks there and one dozer [on site] ... it is currently being controlled," he said.</p><p>"The suspected cause appears to be lightning."</p><p>Mr Shepherd said currently there is no risk to property.</p><p>NSWRFS crew were on scene at a separate forest fire burning near Barrakee Road at Black Springs.</p><p>This fire began on Monday at 4.55pm but by 8pm crews from eight RFS trucks had contained the blaze.</p><p>Mr Shepherd said three trucks of firefighters remain on scene to patrol the area and ensure any hot spots are "blacked out".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CENWES-3733168</dc:identifier><dc:source
